urn:contentItem:5PJ4-N861-JBHT-D0B0-00000-00Mexico Was Rocked With A 7.1 Magnitude Earthquake On The 32 Anniversary Of The Country's Massive 1985 Earthquake; Category Hurricane2017-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:37ZLexisNexisMexico Was Rocked With A 7.1 Magnitude Earthquake On The 32 Anniversary Of The Country's Massive 1985 Earthquake; Category HurricaneLanhamFULL TEXT

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS: This is a Fox News alert. I'm Bret Baier at the White House. We are following two breaking stories of two potential natural disasters. On the left of your screen you're looking at scenes from Mexico. A Magnitude 7.1 earthquake has rocked that nation on the 32nd anniversary of the massive 1985 quake that killed thousands. Right now the governor of one central Mexican state has at least 42 people are dead, but that number is expected to rise. The U.S. geological survey says the quake was centered about 76 miles southeast of Mexico City. We'll have a live report from our west coast newsroom shortly. On the right hand of your screen, Hurricane Maria is bearing down on the Caribbean right now. It is a category 5 hurricane with winds of 165 miles per hour. It is going over much of the same territory that was ravaged by Hurricane Irma just days ago. Puerto Rico is bracing for a major hit tomorrow. We'll have the latest from our Fox weather center, and we'll go to Puerto Rico where our own Steve Harrigan has just arrived on the scene. There is a third top story today, and it is out of New York, President Trump making his first speech to the United Nations General Assembly, and he made quite a first impression.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: We meet at a time of both immense promise and great peril. The depraved regime in North Korea. Rocket man is on a suicide mission for himself and for his regime. We must work together and confront together those who threaten us with chaos, turmoil and terror. The Iran deal was one of the worst and most one-sided transactions. We cannot abide by an agreement if it provides cover for the eventual construction of a nuclear program.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: He was not shy in trying to rally the world against the nuclear ambitions of Iran and North Korea. Chief White House correspondent John Roberts is outside the U.N. tonight. Good evening, John. Quite a speech.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret, good evening to you. It was quite a speech, but it was exactly what the president intended. He came to Washington to be a disruptor, to shake things up, and that's what he did here at the United Nations in his speech this morning. The president was really reaching out to the United Nations to do something about North Korea. I mean, clearly, if North Korea does get a thermonuclear warhead that it can mount on an intercontinental ballistic missile and were to fire one towards the United States, well, that would unleash the total destruction that President Trump threatened this morning. But don't forget, he said if the United States is forced to defend itself, it will totally destroy North Korea. But that is not the president's preferred course of action. He has said that. His aides have said that. So what the president would really like to see is for the United Nations Security Council to come together to impose more tough sanctions on North Korea. For China and Russia to use their collective influence against North Korea. He slapped, as Nikki Haley said he would, the right people, and he hugged the right people, according to the U.S. delegation. And the president did reach out and gave a nice big hug to China and Russia, thanking them for their actions last week at the U.N. Security Council in passing these tough new sanctions. So, while people like Dianne Feinstein are criticizing the president, Bret, for using his United Nations speech as a platform to threaten war, the president sees it completely the opposite, saying those would be the ultimate consequences if something doesn't happen with North Korea. Now it's time for the U.N. to act. Bret?

BAIER: Interesting to hear the ambassador from Venezuela say that he thought he was listening to Ronald Reagan in 1982 as a jab.

ROBERTS: You know, yeah -- Jorge Arreaza, he's the foreign minister of Venezuela, who's reacting to the president, calling out the Nicholas Medora regime, saying it wasn't a failed imposition of socialism. It was a faithful imposition of socialism. Calling it a corrupt dictatorship which has stolen democracy from the people of Venezuela. Well, Arreaza came back out, accused President Trump of reigniting the cold war saying he didn't know if he was listening to Ronald Reagan in 1982 when he was talking tough about the Soviet Union or Donald Trump in 2017. Note to the Venezuelan prime minister, if you're going to try to insult a Republican, don't compare him or her to Ronald Reagan. Bret?

BAIER: John, we'll see you at 6:00 PM. Thank you. We'll also have a live interview with secretary of state Rex Tillerson in the next hour. But first, let's get some analysis of the president's speech. Dana Perino is co-host of The Five, she is in New York, and Chris Stirewalt is Fox News politics editor, he's in our Washington bureau. Dana, first to you, your thought on the speech.

DANA PERINO, THE FIVE CO-HOST: Well, presidential speeches in their maiden voyage to the United Nation General Assembly are often defining moments of a presidency. It only happens once a year. And I love that today President Trump had the stage to himself. And that meant that -- not only was he there to give a speech, but there were some people that weren't there. I think it's good that President Putin and President Xi, Russia and China weren't there, so that he could have the stage and the world could listen to him. And if you see people on the right, even people who might consider themselves sort of moderate or the neo-cons, they love the speech.

The left seems alarmed but at least they have something, which is a defined foreign policy. They've been sort of wondering where is he going to fall on this or that. This was a speech that was really grand in scope. It didn't touch everything. It didn't hit everybody's words, like freedom and liberty. Maybe that wasn't in there as much. But he did talk about diplomacy and how the United Nations could be better. And I think that it was just well received, not just on the right but even in the middle. The left are going to be upset no matter what. But I would say that he really rose to the occasion today and gave a great speech.

BAIER: Now Chris, there were strains in here that you could hear from other Republican presidents, definitely. But there were Trumpian moments, the rocket man moment and other phrases. What's interesting is if you look at the scope of speeches though -- there, you see the joint address to congress, and then you see Saudi Arabia, then you see Warsaw, and that speech in Poland, the Afghan policy rollout, and then you have today. I mean, you're beginning to see the contours of Trump doctrine that is America first, but other countries can be independently able to handle their own issues too.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Yeah. And more humane and thoughtful version of the Trumpism. I thought of two speeches when I heard the president today. One was -- remember when he went to Mexico, went down there and it was not a good look. He was -- seemed very uncomfortable on the world stage. When he went down and he had his meeting with the Mexican president, and it looked like he came out on the short end of that. You can thrash that to today, where he was in command, and he was speaking authoritatively on subjects that were complex. He put forward -- I know it didn't sound nuanced, but there were nuanced points that he made throughout. And he put forward a basically straightforward American foreign policy that, as you said, could have come from the mouths of almost any Republican president.

BAIER: Yeah. Dana, the one thing that a lot of critics are focusing on is that North Korea threat. And they're leaving out the, if, part of that sentence. If North Korea and Kim Jong-un do this, then this is going to happen. I wonder what the message -- how it's going to be digested by countries like China.

PERINO: Well, one of the things you've also heard the administration say that they're out of road. You had McMaster, Haley, and Tillerson, all saying that over the weekend. So that's actually means that they are trying to send quite a clear message. Remember, that when a president speaks he's not only speaking to the people that are directly in front of him or even those that are on television. This was a message meant directly for Kim Jong-un, and I'm sure the president words are going to be parsed. And they were going to try to think, what does he mean by that?

And I actually think in this occasion, when it comes to presidential speeches, you do not have to wonder what President Trump would actually do. What he's saying is it was a strong warning. And it was enough also to get the attention of the world to say I'm actually not kidding. We are at the end of the road. And you're very survival, the people that you care about that you're here representing, it all comes down to us. So we will actively have to. And you're right. The important word is, if. It might be the first time that a world leader was given a nickname on stage at the United Nations. I don't know if it will become routine, but rocket man will never be the same.

BAIER: I didn't know what the over-under was about the marble being commented on at the U.N. But rocket man is surely going to get in. Chris, final thought here, what else struck your ear of this speech? There were some pointed criticism of the U.N. overall, but also some praise for what they can get done in the U.N. Security Council.

STIREWALT: So Trump's foreign policy has evolved rather rapidly over the course of his presidency. There's been considerable move towards -- as we talked about before, normal, a more normal, predictable American foreign policy than what we've been expecting. But his tough talk about North Korea before makes his challenge greater because every president has had to come to terms with, eventually, the fact that there is no good solution for North Korea, and there continues not to be one. Now, because of the way that Trump addressed the problem when he came into office. Status quo is not an option, and the North Koreans continue to escalate the situation. This one is intractable and he's going to need to pull off a Hail Mary on this.

BAIER: And Dana, there was a tease in here, and sometimes Trump speeches include that, like coming up next week, the Iran deal and whether there is going to be some change.

PERINO: There is a deadline of October 15 for the president to respond to congress. I think that if you look at Nikki Haley's speech from about two weeks ago at the American Enterprise Institute, she laid out pretty much what's going to happen, which is the United States would basically say this deal is not good. And congress, if you look at the law, the law congress passed, it's up to them to decide what to do going forward. And I think that the president will say that's what he expects them to do. So, now congress' list just got a little bit longer.

BAIER: All right. Dana, Chris, as always, thank you.

STIREWALT: You bet.

BAIER: This is a Fox News alert. At least 42 people are now dead in a massive earthquake that struck central Mexico today. Correspondent Trace Gallagher is in our west coast newsroom tonight with the latest. Good evening, Trace.

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret. Before I show you more of these disturbing pictures of the earthquake destruction in and around Mexico City. I want to, kind of, give you an idea of the area. The 7.1 quake hit 70 miles south of Mexico City in the state of Puebla. We have not gotten a death toll in Puebla, but in the next-door state of Morelos, the governor there said the death toll is now at 42. In Mexico City, which is in the district of Mexico, two people have died. But if you look at these pictures of collapsed buildings and buckled bridges, the death toll will almost certainly rise. We know there are numerous people trapped inside some of these fallen buildings, but it's unclear if authorities are in contact with these people.

We are also getting word that dozens, if not hundreds of roads in and out of Mexico City are fractured and impossible, which means the recovery effort will be that much slower, especially in the very vulnerable areas outside of Mexico City where millions of poor people live. Thirty two years ago today, an 8.0 quake in Mexico City claimed at least 5,000 lives and thousands of buildings. Now the construction codes have become much stricter over the past three decades, but in the poorer areas there are hundreds of thousands of structures that have not been retrofitted or reinforce. So it's worth noting, Mexico City was built on a dry lake bed, so earthquake waves tend to echo and multiply the damage. Dry lake beds are also prone to liquefaction, which means the ground simply turns to water.

And in the outlying areas of Mexico where millions of poor people live, there are still many buildings, again, that are not reinforced. Even though the epicenter of this quake was 70 miles south of Mexico City, because it was 32 miles deep the damage will be felt over a very wide area. And for some context, today's quake in Mexico City was six times stronger than the 6.9 quake that hit San Francisco in 1989, 12 times stronger than the quake that hit Northridge, California, in 1994. And, of course, just last week, Bret, an 8.1 quake in the southwestern part of Mexico killed 58 people. The death toll of this Mexico City quake will certainly rise in the hours ahead, Bret.

BAIER: It's a big story. And we'll head back with breaking details as they become available. Trace, thank you. Who has the presidents back after his speech today at the U.N.? We'll find out after the break. Plus, health care, Russia, and the budget. A tick-tock of what's happening on Capitol Hill. And we're watching that big storm out there, Hurricane Maria. Next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Here at the White House today, we do this once a week. Meantime, just down Pennsylvania Avenue, congress has more than a full plate in the final 11 days of this fiscal year. Let's get more on that tonight from Fox senior Capitol Hill producer Chad Pergram. He's at the capitol this evening. Good evening, Chad.

CHAD PERGRAM, FOX NEWS SENIOR CAPITOL HILL PRODUCER: Good evening.

BAIER: You know, we're talking about a lot of things, but really on the focus for a lot of folks is health care. We thought efforts to repeal and replace Obamacare might be finished, might be done. But now, they've been resurrected. Explain what's going on.

PERGRAM: This is like one of those old horror movies, Bret, where they think that they've killed off the monster, and yet, it's really alive and keeps coming around the corner. You can almost hear the creepy music. That's the take the Democrats say, because they thought they killed this off. There's going to be an effort to try to resurrect this by Republicans in the next week and a half. They've only have until September 30th to use this special process which avoids filibusters, and then it goes poof. It goes away.

Now, the thing about health care is that it's always been about the math. The average repeal and replace bill would always get in the upper 40's in the Republican side. They need at least 50 with Vice President Pence to potentially break a tie here. John McCain and Susan Collins are on the fence. Collins says that this bill is more flawed than the last one. Rand Paul is a hard no. And so, what a lot of people are looking at, Lisa Murkowski, the Republican senator from Alaska. I have senior sources here telling me that all roads lead to her. And they would have to move this next week. Vice president Pence was at the capitol today talking to Republican senators about this, and he says it's all in. And they have to get this off the table so they can go to tax reform next, Bret.

BAIER: Yeah. And we should point out the Cassidy-Graham bill, essentially is a federalist version, pushes a lot of it to the states. So we're watching those votes. Next week, a big week, as you mentioned, for tax reform in congress.

PERGRAM: Right. And what we expect is Kevin Brady, the chairman of the ways and means committee from Texas, to put out some general specifics here. This has been the criticism from Republicans that they don't have enough specifics. People who've been riding this bill say, yes, you do. But we'll actually see what the proof is in the pudding when they put that together next week. Kevin Brady has not yet scheduled a markup section. That would be the signal to know that they're really getting somewhere in the committee. And again, Republicans have always been in general agreement on tax reform. The devil will be in the details on this and that's what's going to be hard. And that might be why they need Democrats, and they need to avoid a filibuster, and that's why they need a second special budget reconciliation package which neuters those filibusters.

BAIER: Yeah, a lot of moving parts up on the hill. The senate intelligence committee today heard from President Trump's personal attorney Michael Cohen as part of this Russian investigation, but it didn't really all go as well as planned.

PERGRAM: That's right. And that's because he leaked out some of the information that he was going to tell the committee. They didn't like that. Richard Burr, the chairman of the committee, Republican senator from North Carolina, indicated that you don't get to say things in public and then say other things in private. And so, just in the past 15 minutes or so here, they've asked Michael Cohen to appear in a public session on the 25th of October.

BAIER: OK. Chad Pergram with all the latest up on Capitol Hill. Chad, thanks. As we mentioned at the top of the show, Hurricane Maria tearing through the Caribbean tonight. It's going over a lot of the same territory already devastated, unfortunately, by Hurricane Irma. Let's get the latest on the storm's path from meteorologist Adam Klotz. He's in the Fox weather center in New York. Adam, Puerto Rico looks like it's in the target range.

ADAM KLOTZ, FOX NEWS METEOROLOGIST: Yeah, it is. Overnight tonight, Bret, into tomorrow, really throughout the day tomorrow, that's what we're going to be looking at. Here it is. It's a big storm. Winds currently at 165 miles an hour. Gusting at times even up to 190, 185, right around there. So it's a powerful one. Going to continue to move that direction. As a category five storm, you are going to see this -- maybe weakened a little bit once it begins to run over the U.S. Virgin Islands, over Puerto Rico. But either way, a very powerful storm. Following there to a category four.

Really think early, early tomorrow morning to the U.S. Virgin Islands, throughout the day tomorrow. Folks in Puerto Rico are going to be dealing with it. We've saw a little bit of indecision on specifically where it's going to cross over the island, but either way it looks like the largest city, San Juan, is going to be heavily impacted with this. You see it eventually begin to turn just east of the Bahamas before it heads to the north.

So no concerns for Florida with this particular system, even though it's a system that is taking, at least, early on, a similar path to Irma. The big concerns, initially, are going to be these winds as they cross over yet the U.S. Virgin Islands, and then into Puerto Rico tomorrow. All of these getting hurricane force winds. That's what that is indicating, right in that area. What kind of winds that I'm talking about? Real quickly here, these are some of the wind gusts forecasted for you on Wednesday, getting up to about 120, 130, in some areas. This is going to be a real powerful storm, Bret.

BAIER: Adam, thanks. We'll track that. Back over to the United Nation now, Israel's prime minister gave President Trump some serious backup today at the U.N. Senior correspondent Eric Shawn is there tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Let's give this as a toast to the potential, the great, great potential of the United Nations.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ERIC SHAWN, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPINDENT: While the international spotlight was on President Trump's debut on the world body stage, other leaders echoed similar themes warning of threats to the global order. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu focus on Iran. Each year he has used the annual General Assembly platform to denounce Iran's nuclear ambitions. And did so, yet, again, today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BENJAMIN NETANYAHU, ISRAEL PRIME MINISTER: President Trump rightly called the nuclear deal with Iran, he called it an embarrassment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN: The Israeli leader is calling for the agreement, in his words, to be fixed or canceled. Saying revisions that left a restriction on Iran's nuclear program in ten years will certainly clear the way for a nuclear bomb.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NETANYAHU: Fix it or nix it. Nixing the deal means restoring massive pressure on Iran, including crippling sanctions until Iran fully dismantles its nuclear weapons capability. Fixing the deal requires many things, among them inspecting military and any other sites that is a suspect.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN: In a little noticed development, Netanyahu had a private sit down with Egyptian president, Abdel el-Sisi, an important bond with Israel's Arab neighbor that has also suffered numerous terrorist attacks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNINDENTIFIED MALE: I would like to speak in favor of the nuclear agreement with Iran.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN: But in contrast to President Trump and Netanyahu's view, French president, Emmanuel Macron, praise the Iran deal, saying changing or scrapping it would be a mistake.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNINDENTIFIED MALE: If we put together a solid, robust, and fare agreement with Iran that, will ensure that Iran does not obtain nuclear weapons. Renouncing it would be a grave error. It would be irresponsible for us to fail to uphold that agreement because this is good agreement.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN: The Venezuelan foreign minister reacted sharply to President Trump's speech, saying he came to talk of war, treats the countries like his employees. It's a sad day for the world, he said. Tomorrow, there'll likely be more reaction. That's when it's Iranian president Hassan Rouhani's turn to speak before the green marble podium of the General Assembly. Bret?

BAIER: Eric Shawn outside of the United Nation. Eric, thanks. Stay with us. Millions of people personal information compromised. Now Equifax is admitting it's not the first time. Plus, rough sailing for the U.S. navy, and now the top admirals are facing tough questions. Keep it here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Welcome back to the White House. The last few months have been anything but smooth sailing for the U.S. navy. A series of accidents has led to the deaths of 17 sailors and the replacement of several senior officers. Today, some of those still left were on Capitol Hill. National security correspondent Jennifer Griffin has the latest tonight from the Pentagon. Good evening, Jennifer.

JENNIFER GRIFFIN, FOX NEWS NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret. Angry lawmakers directed tough questions at the navy's top officer, Admiral John Richardson, while family members of the victim sat behind him. Richardson admitted today that changes to training may be part of the problem. In 2003, the navy closed its surface warfare schoolhouse.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNINDENTIFIED MALE: We thought we could achieve the aim and then train surface warfare officers, junior officers with a computer-based approach combined with on-the-job training at sea. And we found that was woefully inadequate.

UNINDENTIFIED MALE: How in the world is a billion-dollar destroyer not know that there's a freighter closing in on it? I don't understand how this could possibly happen. And I've talked to Maine lobstermen, they're scratching their heads. They can tell when there's a flock of seagulls of their bowels. Don't we have sailors on the bridge with binoculars anymore?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GRIFFIN: Many of them, watch officers, are exhausted. The chief of naval operations admitted many sailors are working 100 hour weeks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JOHN MCCAIN, R-ARIZONA: I think I know what 100 hours a week does to people over time. When somebody is working 100 hours a week, over a period of time, they're going to make mistakes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GRIFFIN: For McCain, this is a personal one. One of the two destroyers that crashed was named for his father and grandfather. The Navy is down to two destroyers, badly needed right now in the Pacific, both capable of shooting down North Korean missiles.

The outgoing head of the Navy's surface forces has ordered all Navy ships to keep their automatic identification systems on while operating in busy shipping lanes. It will alert adversities to the location of the U.S warships, the system can force merchant ships on autopilot to change course. He also wants to get rid of five hour watches the Navy. Six Navy leaders have been fired since the collisions.

Rear admiral Charles Williams and Captain Bennett were terminated yesterday. One-third of all Navy Warship training certifications have expired, according to a government watchdog. Those ships are still sailing. Today the Navy Officers admitted ten of the USS Fitzgerald certifications had expired at the time of the crash.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: A big story for the Navy. Jennifer Griffin live at the Pentagon. Thank you. New trouble tonight for Equifax, the credit card monitoring company was dealing with the fallout from a massive security breach. Now we are learning it was not the first. Equifax says the earlier incident was not related to the most recent breach which compromised the personal information of more than 140 billion Americans. Let's get more from Fox business network, good evening.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX NEWS HOST: Some industry watchers were speculating that hackers did the first tack and marked as a test for the bigger one that followed. Equifax saying that's not the case. After the March hack, Equifax hired an outside security firm which was retained to help with the May through July data set.

Equifax says they found no evidence these two hacks were related but its worth noting they have declined to comment. What cast longer of a shadow is there's evidence that Equifax executives should have realized how vulnerable their company was. This March hack casting doubts on claims of these three high level executives who said they had no knowledge of data breaches selling $2 million worth of stock this summer.

Some experts say if you believe three high ranking executives didn't know about one breach, it's less believable that they were unaware of two breachers. They have opened a criminal probe into Equifax. Earlier today, the Attorney General filed a suit against Equifax. This matches with New York Attorney General did. This is a sign of things to come. It's worth cyber experts say none of the data from this Equifax pack showed up anywhere. In other words, it's not for sale.

All of the social security numbers, dates of birth and some cases driver's license numbers. It's not on sale on the web. A lot of experts are saying the lack of commercial activity is near proof that state sponsored group is behind this big data breach. May through July Data breach affected 40% of Americans. The theory is a hack this big and sophisticated must be the work of a governmental organization. People can only protect themselves by only freezing their credit reports.

BAIER: It's a good thing to do. Thank you. Next up, President Trump threatens North Korea and blisters Iran and Venezuela. We will get reaction to his U.N speech from our panel. A little later, I will ask secretary of state Rex Tillerson out the fallout from the speech in the latest hot spots around the world.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The United States has great strength and patience. But if it's forced to defend itself or it's allies, we will have no choice but to totally destroy North Korea. Rocket man is on a suicide mission for himself and for his regime. No nation on Earth has an interest in seeing this band of criminals arm itself with Nuclear weapons and missiles.

BAIER: President Trump at the United States today, a speech that's getting a lot of reaction here and around the world. Democratic Senator saying this. Dianne Feinstein "President Trumps Bombastic threat to destroy North Korea and his refusal to present any positive pathways forward on many global challenges we face are severe disappointments.

He aims to unify the world through tactics of intimidation but in reality, he only further isolates the United States." Republicans came out with positive tweets and reaction as well as a the Israeli Prime Minister with the big kudos. Lets bring the panel. Joining me at the White House, Catherine Lucey, White House reported for the associated press. From the Washington Bureau, Katie Pavlich. Charles Hart, opinion editor for the "Washington Times". It was bold, direct.

CATHERINE LUCY, WHITE HOUSE REPORTER: He really put the world on Notice today. The president came in with a clear message. I've been watching his speeches throughout the year and the campaign, it was a continuation of a vintage and of a vision we've seen before. He revealed his frustration and the way he thinks, and it's the way he thinks that needs to deliver the message. This is the kind of rhetoric he's comfortable with. This is the way he wants to communicate. He wanted to make a stand today.

BAIER: We have seen these kinds of speeches before. I mentioned Saudi Arabia and Warsaw big speeches. It's a bit of a Trump doctrine that's forming here.

CHARLES HURT, WASHINGTON TIMES: Absolutely. I think a fairly consistent Trump Doctrine and a departure from the kind of speeches you would hear from President Obama a year ago when he was giving a similar speech before the U.N. He was talking about how America had to learn to subjugate its interests for other countries and just sort of rein in some of our freedom in order to make better, grander world.

Donald Trump went out there talking about how much more money we're going to invest in our military we've ever been, and then went names and terms of calling out enemies. And then went out to even criticize the U.N for completely failing in central parts of its mission. I look back and I cannot think of another -- even George W. Bush who got sort of criticized for being somewhat of a cowboy wouldn't have delivered a speech like this. This is tough stuff. I think a lot of people are thrilled to hear it.

BAIER: He mentioned Russia and China wants. I want to play this sound bite. Russia and China, the leaders, were not in the room at the time. Here is that part.

TRUMP: We must reject threats to sovereignty from the Ukraine to South China Sea. It's time for North Korea to realize that the denuclearization is its only acceptable future. I want to thank China and Russia for joining the vote to impose sanctions along with all the other members of the Security Council.

BAIER: He mentioned China, except for that once, they North Korea part was aimed at China specifically.

KATIE PAVLICH, AMERICAN JOURNALIST: This is going to be the next step here, we saw a lot coming from President Trump today in terms of rhetoric and he's a man who expects results. We've had these votes on sanctions now. The Chinese and Russians have signed on, and the question going forward is going to be due this sanctions get enforced and does the U.N make sure those sanctions get enforced?

In terms of the general message and theme of the speech, he did reject globalism as Charlie was saying, of Americans giving some of their ideology to fit into this global -- international community. At the same time, did not reject international partnerships with different countries in terms of solving the big problems on North Korea and Iran. I think that goes to show he's very serious that it's an America first but not alone.

BAIER: What about the tease about the Iran Nuclear deal? It seemed like he suggested there'll be some sort of change.

LUCY: It's possible. He didn't tell us today what's going to happen. He had tough rhetoric today. He has been very clear. He was vocal last week that he's not happy with the deal. We're going to have to wait a little bit longer to see exactly what he does.

BAIER: I will be asking the Secretary of State about that next hour. Charlie, final thoughts on the broad messaging here. You've got North Korea, Iran, Venezuela, Radical Islamic terrorism, taking target to all of it.

HURT: Much like everything we've seen with we've seen with the Trump Presidency from his election, so much of it is a rejection of the previous administration and the previous administration strategic patience in North Korea or the Iran deal of Russia's entanglement, broadening entanglement come all over its region and interference in our election. This really is not only a domestic slap in the face to the previous administration. Lawyer seeing here is a stark departure from the Obama administration policies.

BAIER: Panel, standby. Washington Versus Silicon Valley, up next.

(COMMERICAL BREAK)

BAIER: Gorgeous day here at the White House. The heads of Facebook are under new scrutiny tonight over how they may have unwittingly helped Russia's efforts to influence last year's U.S election. This is part of a growing backlash here in Washington towards Silicon Valley. Correspondent Kristen Fisher reports.

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX CORRESPONDENT: The tech giants have long been admired by congress, companies that embodies American innovations in job creation. But then the 2016 election happened. Big Tech could be in big trouble on Capitol Hill.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTCIPANT: I think frankly they need to come and testify before congress because there's a lot we need to know about this.

FISHER: Right now to no company is a bigger target than Facebook from unwittingly allowing the spread of fake news during the campaign to Facebook's most recent admission selling thousands of ads to groups backed by the Russian government.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTCIPANT: I am distressed it's taken this long to be informed that the Russians had paid for at least $100,000 of ads designed or tried to influence our electoral process.

FISHER: Congressman Adam distressed that Facebook shared evidence with the special counsel but not his committee, which is also investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election. Added up and you can see why analysts say this may be the moment congress turns its back on big tech.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We are entering an era of accountability because we have system platforms that reached nearly every citizen in the country.

FISHER: Last night Hillary Clinton called the weaponization of information on social media --

HILARY CLINTON: One of the most serious challenges we face going forward in politics.

UNITENTIFIED MALE: And it's not just democrats. Republicans worry about the amount influence these companies exert over the American electorate, anti liberal. There's been almost no supervision.

FISHER: Facebook once called himself a social utility. Now the question facing congress is whether it and the rest of Big Tech should be regulated as one.

MCMASTER: This is the equivalent of gigantic public utilities. The information has enormous power and I don't think even in a free society you can have power hidden in secret controlled by a handful of billionaires.

FISHER: Now we ask facebook officials if they will be willing to be interviewed. They declined to except to say the company will continue to work with U.S authorities investigating these issues. Bret?

BAIER: Kristen, thank you. Back to the panel. Katie, Charlie, Catherine. Katie, what about this? Is it turning of the tide? There is always some evil villain if you will, somewhere. Is it Silicon valley?

PAVLICH: I think the government has to shred very lightly when it comes to their goals. This is a very political hunch for people in Silicon Valley. I'm not exactly sure what the government is trying to get out of Facebook and these big tech giants. These are serious questions here. Not only about Facebook's operations as a private company.

And what they are allowed to do. They are allowed to sell ads to whoever they want. They are providing a service whether the government should be regulating batch. And there is serious questions about their clients, so to speak, and whether the government should be regulating what private people say in private business on the internet.

BAIER: Stew on the Facebook statement, we should point out says the vast majority of ads run by these accounts, didn't specifically reference the U.S presidential election. Voting, or particular candidate rather the ads and accounts appeared to focus on amplifying divisive social and political messages across the ideological spectrum. That was the Facebook Staement.

LUCY: Yes and I think as the reporting reached a (inaudible) was saying this is a new moment of accountability for Facebook, and how is that going to unfold. There's law makers with a lot of question. It seems like they're either going to want to bring people in, could there be hearings, could Mark Sufferberg have to come in and testify. That's certainly something that's being speculated on. But I think the other issue we're going to have to look at is, what might regulation look like. And I don't know if that there's been a consensus on it, and how that would work, because there isn't a ton of president on how we do this.

BAIER: And that is the question Charlie, I mean if you start going down the regulation road and it seems like we're heading down that way. For the longest time Silicon Valley has said, you know they're bigger if you will than Washington and didn't pay a ton of attention to inside Washington Politics, but now they may have to.

HURT: Yes and the whole thing sort of high lights, what I would call another false failed promise, from the federal government, where congress tried to regulate with (inaudible) sort of stuff with campaign finance reform. And what happened in the end was -- and remember you're mucking with freedom of speech, you're mucking with people's ability to say what they want to say, and put as much money as they want to behind a message in order to express, to express yourself. And so through campaign finance reforms, we had this weird situation where average Americans are capped at how much they can give, how much of their speech is allowed to be paid for, to promote certain candidates and then Russia and these maul factors that are from outside of the country, who aren't even -- who don't'-- none of these laws pertain to. You walk in and drop $100,000 worth of propaganda on us. And I think it is a very dangerous thing that we're dealing with, and we have to deal with it very carefully. And these lawmakers that talk like there's simple answer through campaign finance reform, we have to be skeptically of that.

BAIER: Yes, and Katie the big thing there is the Russia part. The outside country that is investing in whatever they are investing in.

PAVLICH: And there is presentment in terms of the law allowing foreign donations to campaigns in America. So maybe they could use that in terms of some of the regulation that there going to come up with. But when it comes to what they're regulating, it really just seems like they're going after Facebook based on not a lot of evidence that Russia was actually working with Facebook to promote Donald Trump, and not to mention Facebook had nothing to do with people actually going to the polls and deciding which candidate they were going to vote for. So I quite frankly at this point, see this as a little bit of a witch hunt for -- on capitol hill for these government panels, these congressional committees who are trying to find something on Russia, going after a private company, and private citizens for simply exercising their free speech.

BAIER: Catherine, we don't know much about Bob Maulers investigation, but we do know that he has information from Facebook that the Capitol Hill committees don't.

LUCY: I think we really do know here is that the investigation is heating up. There's been a lot of reports this week about the things they're doing and it's not going away. Whatever happens with facebook, t hat's going to keep moving, and it's going to keep being you know a concern for this White House.

BAIER: And does it -- is there an end date? Do they have an expiration date enable to make their case on all these?

LUCY: Not that I'm -- I mean I think the investigation is continuing and a lot of people are saying it could go on for quite awhile.

BAIER: Do you agree Charlie?

HURT: I think it's -- that is possible. And I think that the longer it goes on, I think it gets more and more complicated for democrats. Politically because of course, you know as long as you keep pointing to these smoking guns, but there's clearly not been any real hard evidence that anybody within the Trump Campaign actually did anything to conclude with Russia. It makes all of this look like somewhat of a Witch Hunt.

BAIER: We will follow it all. Panel, as always thank you. That does it for hour number one. A special report a brand new hour, including a live interview with the secretary of state. Coming up after a quick break.

END

urn:contentItem:5PHV-4MT1-JB20-G36P-00000-00Mexico Was Rocked With A 7.1 Magnitude Earthquake On The 32 Anniversary Of The Country's Massive 1985 Earthquake; Category Hurricane Maria Bearing Down On The Caribbean, While Puerto Rico Is Bracing For A Major Hit Tomorrow; President Donald Trump Making His First Speech To The United Nation General Assembly, Focus On North Korea And Iran; Once Dormant Health Care Overhaul, Now Revived; Lawmaker Grill Navy Over Recent Accidents At Sea; One Of The Two Navy Destroyers Crashed Was Named After John McCain's Father and Grandfather; Donald Trump Sends A Threatening Message To North Korea; Washington's Growing Backlash for Silicon Valley2017-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:37ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS5:00 PM ESTChad Pergram, Adam Klotz, Eric Shawn, Jennifer Griffin, Charles Hurt, Katie PavlichNEWSDomestic091901cb.262Mexico Was Rocked With A 7.1 Magnitude Earthquake On The 32 Anniversary Of The Country's Massive 1985 Earthquake; Category Hurricane Maria Bearing Down On The Caribbean, While Puerto Rico Is Bracing For A Major Hit Tomorrow; President Donald Trump Making His First Speech To The United Nation General Assembly, Focus On North Korea And Iran; Once Dormant Health Care Overhaul, Now Revived; Lawmaker Grill Navy Over Recent Accidents At Sea; One Of The Two Navy Destroyers Crashed Was Named After John McCain's Father and Grandfather; Donald Trump Sends A Threatening Message To North Korea; Washington's Growing Backlash for Silicon ValleyJohn Roberts, Dana Perino, Chris Stirewalt, Trace Gallagher, Bret Baierr, Jennifer Griffin, Kristin Fisher, Deidre Bolton

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS: This is a Fox News alert. I'm Bret Baier at the White House. We are following two breaking stories of two potential natural disasters. On the left of your screen you're looking at scenes from Mexico. A Magnitude 7.1 earthquake has rocked that nation on the 32nd anniversary of the massive 1985 quake that killed thousands. Right now the governor of one central Mexican state has at least 42 people are dead, but that number is expected to rise. The U.S. geological survey says the quake was centered about 76 miles southeast of Mexico City. We'll have a live report from our west coast newsroom shortly. On the right hand of your screen, Hurricane Maria is bearing down on the Caribbean right now. It is a category 5 hurricane with winds of 165 miles per hour. It is going over much of the same territory that was ravaged by Hurricane Irma just days ago. Puerto Rico is bracing for a major hit tomorrow. We'll have the latest from our Fox weather center, and we'll go to Puerto Rico where our own Steve Harrigan has just arrived on the scene. There is a third top story today, and it is out of New York, President Trump making his first speech to the United Nations General Assembly, and he made quite a first impression.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: We meet at a time of both immense promise and great peril. The depraved regime in North Korea. Rocket man is on a suicide mission for himself and for his regime. We must work together and confront together those who threaten us with chaos, turmoil and terror. The Iran deal was one of the worst and most one-sided transactions. We cannot abide by an agreement if it provides cover for the eventual construction of a nuclear program.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: He was not shy in trying to rally the world against the nuclear ambitions of Iran and North Korea. Chief White House correspondent John Roberts is outside the U.N. tonight. Good evening, John. Quite a speech.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret, good evening to you. It was quite a speech, but it was exactly what the president intended. He came to Washington to be a disruptor, to shake things up, and that's what he did here at the United Nations in his speech this morning. The president was really reaching out to the United Nations to do something about North Korea. I mean, clearly, if North Korea does get a thermonuclear warhead that it can mount on an intercontinental ballistic missile and were to fire one towards the United States, well, that would unleash the total destruction that President Trump threatened this morning. But don't forget, he said if the United States is forced to defend itself, it will totally destroy North Korea. But that is not the president's preferred course of action. He has said that. His aides have said that. So what the president would really like to see is for the United Nations Security Council to come together to impose more tough sanctions on North Korea. For China and Russia to use their collective influence against North Korea. He slapped, as Nikki Haley said he would, the right people, and he hugged the right people, according to the U.S. delegation. And the president did reach out and gave a nice big hug to China and Russia, thanking them for their actions last week at the U.N. Security Council in passing these tough new sanctions. So, while people like Dianne Feinstein are criticizing the president, Bret, for using his United Nations speech as a platform to threaten war, the president sees it completely the opposite, saying those would be the ultimate consequences if something doesn't happen with North Korea. Now it's time for the U.N. to act. Bret?

BAIER: Interesting to hear the ambassador from Venezuela say that he thought he was listening to Ronald Reagan in 1982 as a jab.

ROBERTS: You know, yeah -- Jorge Arreaza, he's the foreign minister of Venezuela, who's reacting to the president, calling out the Nicholas Medora regime, saying it wasn't a failed imposition of socialism. It was a faithful imposition of socialism. Calling it a corrupt dictatorship which has stolen democracy from the people of Venezuela. Well, Arreaza came back out, accused President Trump of reigniting the cold war saying he didn't know if he was listening to Ronald Reagan in 1982 when he was talking tough about the Soviet Union or Donald Trump in 2017. Note to the Venezuelan prime minister, if you're going to try to insult a Republican, don't compare him or her to Ronald Reagan. Bret?

BAIER: John, we'll see you at 6:00 PM. Thank you. We'll also have a live interview with secretary of state Rex Tillerson in the next hour. But first, let's get some analysis of the president's speech. Dana Perino is co-host of The Five, she is in New York, and Chris Stirewalt is Fox News politics editor, he's in our Washington bureau. Dana, first to you, your thought on the speech.

DANA PERINO, THE FIVE CO-HOST: Well, presidential speeches in their maiden voyage to the United Nation General Assembly are often defining moments of a presidency. It only happens once a year. And I love that today President Trump had the stage to himself. And that meant that -- not only was he there to give a speech, but there were some people that weren't there. I think it's good that President Putin and President Xi, Russia and China weren't there, so that he could have the stage and the world could listen to him. And if you see people on the right, even people who might consider themselves sort of moderate or the neo-cons, they love the speech.

The left seems alarmed but at least they have something, which is a defined foreign policy. They've been sort of wondering where is he going to fall on this or that. This was a speech that was really grand in scope. It didn't touch everything. It didn't hit everybody's words, like freedom and liberty. Maybe that wasn't in there as much. But he did talk about diplomacy and how the United Nations could be better. And I think that it was just well received, not just on the right but even in the middle. The left are going to be upset no matter what. But I would say that he really rose to the occasion today and gave a great speech.

BAIER: Now Chris, there were strains in here that you could hear from other Republican presidents, definitely. But there were Trumpian moments, the rocket man moment and other phrases. What's interesting is if you look at the scope of speeches though -- there, you see the joint address to congress, and then you see Saudi Arabia, then you see Warsaw, and that speech in Poland, the Afghan policy rollout, and then you have today. I mean, you're beginning to see the contours of Trump doctrine that is America first, but other countries can be independently able to handle their own issues too.

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS POLITICS EDITOR: Yeah. And more humane and thoughtful version of the Trumpism. I thought of two speeches when I heard the president today. One was -- remember when he went to Mexico, went down there and it was not a good look. He was -- seemed very uncomfortable on the world stage. When he went down and he had his meeting with the Mexican president, and it looked like he came out on the short end of that. You can thrash that to today, where he was in command, and he was speaking authoritatively on subjects that were complex. He put forward -- I know it didn't sound nuanced, but there were nuanced points that he made throughout. And he put forward a basically straightforward American foreign policy that, as you said, could have come from the mouths of almost any Republican president.

BAIER: Yeah. Dana, the one thing that a lot of critics are focusing on is that North Korea threat. And they're leaving out the, if, part of that sentence. If North Korea and Kim Jong-un do this, then this is going to happen. I wonder what the message -- how it's going to be digested by countries like China.

PERINO: Well, one of the things you've also heard the administration say that they're out of road. You had McMaster, Haley, and Tillerson, all saying that over the weekend. So that's actually means that they are trying to send quite a clear message. Remember, that when a president speaks he's not only speaking to the people that are directly in front of him or even those that are on television. This was a message meant directly for Kim Jong-un, and I'm sure the president words are going to be parsed. And they were going to try to think, what does he mean by that?

And I actually think in this occasion, when it comes to presidential speeches, you do not have to wonder what President Trump would actually do. What he's saying is it was a strong warning. And it was enough also to get the attention of the world to say I'm actually not kidding. We are at the end of the road. And you're very survival, the people that you care about that you're here representing, it all comes down to us. So we will actively have to. And you're right. The important word is, if. It might be the first time that a world leader was given a nickname on stage at the United Nations. I don't know if it will become routine, but rocket man will never be the same.

BAIER: I didn't know what the over-under was about the marble being commented on at the U.N. But rocket man is surely going to get in. Chris, final thought here, what else struck your ear of this speech? There were some pointed criticism of the U.N. overall, but also some praise for what they can get done in the U.N. Security Council.

STIREWALT: So Trump's foreign policy has evolved rather rapidly over the course of his presidency. There's been considerable move towards -- as we talked about before, normal, a more normal, predictable American foreign policy than what we've been expecting. But his tough talk about North Korea before makes his challenge greater because every president has had to come to terms with, eventually, the fact that there is no good solution for North Korea, and there continues not to be one. Now, because of the way that Trump addressed the problem when he came into office. Status quo is not an option, and the North Koreans continue to escalate the situation. This one is intractable and he's going to need to pull off a Hail Mary on this.

urn:contentItem:5G8F-2GS1-DYJM-M3P4-00000-00Miami Innovation District idea gaining tech community support;Technology2015-06-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:37ZLexisNexisbusinessMiami Innovation District idea gaining tech community supportTechnology Nancy DahlbergMiami Herald

While debate continues over a 10-acre development centered around a 633-foot LED tower, support is growing among some local entrepreneurs and tech investors for the proposed for the Park West section of downtown.

"I'm becoming pretty passionate about this project," said Andres Moreno, executive chairman of Open English, a fast-growing online education company in Coconut Grove that has attracted $120 million in venture capital. "Miami is definitely coming together as an ecosystem but it is pretty spread out ... We haven't found a hub."

Moreno is among the South Florida entrepreneurs, angel investors and board members of Endeavor Miami who have met with Innovation District developer Michael Simkins to discuss the project. Moreno, who also recently founded Next University, is among the more bullish: He said he would move his companies there.

National players may share his enthusiasm, according to Simkins, who said he is in active discussions with large tech companies as potential anchor tenants. Already lined up, Simkins said, is Silicon Valley's , a well-known global venture fund for early-stage tech companies.

According to Simkins, the "verbal understanding" with 500 Startups calls for the organization to open an accelerator for top Latin American startups in one of the existing buildings on his property, possibly as early as this fall, with the goal of moving to a new tower when complete. Dave McClure, founder of 500 Startups, brought the company's in March and said then to expand to Miami. 500 Startups did not return calls seeking comment for this story.

To be sure, Simkins and his Innovate Development Group have been promoting the benefits of clustering large tech companies, mid-sized companies, startups, incubators, co-working and public spaces, services and cafes in a common area wired with super high speed Internet access as a way to accelerate the growth of a tech ecosystem -- an effort supported locally by the Knight Foundation and eMerge Americas, among others. Similar districts are found in Boston/Cambridge, New York, Seattle, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Las Vegas and one emerging now in downtown Detroit, as well as London, Barcelona, Berlin, Stockholm, Medellin and many other cities, according to a 34-page . Many are in walkable-bikeable urban downtown-midtown areas close to public transportation and contain housing.

"The one thing Miami is lacking as a great city is the high-paying jobs that will allow us to evolve and elevate us overall. We visited innovation districts. We chose an architecture firm that has designed other innovation projects" -- including recently Uber's new headquarters, said Simkins, in an interview in his Miami Beach office. He has not done a project of this scale before.

Simkins's proposal has faced a mountain of negative sentiment that would contain an observation deck, restaurants, retail, event space - and advertising in lights visible from the freeways. An electronic billboard in the sky is one of the nicer ways .

Simkins prefers "a $250 million icon in the sky" and said the tower could also be used for public service messaging - a dashboard for the city if you will. But he is also quick to point out that the media tower, called the Miami Innovation Tower, is just for the live-work-play district, which includes nine towers with 7.4 million square feet - more than half of that earmarked for office space.

But it's the overall concept, not the media tower, that interests the early tech supporters.

What distinguishes successful innovation districts are big tech anchors. Juan Pablo Cappello, a lawyer and co-founder of the AGP angel network, said having a place - with literally the space - to house large companies is what excites him most about the Innovation District plan for Miami.

"If Miami can offer a place where enterprise tech companies like a Google, like a Facebook can have the space and resources to hire 100, 200, 500 people, that could be transformative," Cappello said. "Companies like to cluster ... With a project like this you can get some momentum building."

Patrick McKenna, managing partner of HighRidge Global and an investor and entrepreneur who moved here a year ago from Silicon Valley, saw the power of momentum first hand. About six years ago, he said, San Francisco risked losing Twitter and other tech companies that were outgrowing their spaces. Meetings between the tech community and government ensued. Thanks to tax breaks and the rezoning of blighted sections of the city, the offices of Twitter, Square, Salesforce and Zynga lie within walking distance of one another. A district can attract both critical mass and tech anchor tenants, both critical to Miami's tech development, he said.

Colombia-born entrepreneur Juan Franco, who moved to Miami from Silicon Valley about a decade ago to launch social gaming publisher Mentez and since has started three more companies, met Simkins through YPO, the Young Presidents Network. He, too, is a supporter of the project.

"What is missing here is an environment of entrepreneurs. That is what I like most about this project. ... It will bring people together - young people with new ideas, people with experience, hopefully [venture capitalists] in the future. They are close together and that creates the interactions and the new ideas," said Franco.

Franco even likes the controversial tower: "I believe he [Simkins] needs to create a statement, that's why I like the tower. It could be an icon of the city very related to technology and around the tower we can start to create that excitement."

Moreno said he spent some time recently talking about the importance of frequent collisions - entrepreneur-speak for interactions that happen in tech clusters that Franco spoke about - during a visit with CEO Tony Hsieh, CEO of Zappos and engineer of Las Vegas' innovation district. For Hsieh, moving his company headquarters and more than 2,000 employees there wasn't enough. Hsieh also funded and led a resurgence of a once-blighted downtown area that now includes multiple big companies, startups, services, weekly speaker series, regular conferences, cafes, bars and a dog park.

Matt Haggman, Miami program director of the Knight Foundation, said he has talked with Simkins about the project in concept but has not seen the plans.

"I don't know the details of the proposal, but our focus at Knight Foundation is to expand Miami's entrepreneurial ecosystem, helping it become more diverse and broad-based. Any project that advances those goals would be good for the community," Haggman said. In the past three years, Knight Foundation has invested more than $10 million in Miami entrepreneurship programs.

Simkins plans to continue meeting with tech community leaders and wants to share plans and hear feedback at a future event by Refresh Miami, South Florida's largest tech meet-up organization. He is also taking part in hosted by the Commercial Industrial Association about "Miami's tech footprint" on Thursday. Moreno, a member of the Miami board of the global entrepreneurship nonprofit Endeavor, said a tech community advisory board is being formed for the Miami Innovation District project.

"The developer has spent a lot of time and money on what it will look like, but what will happen inside that venue is still to be defined. As a community, we still have an opportunity to shape this to be a really core part of the ecosystem. I think that is hugely exciting," said Moreno.

Simkins, born and raised in Miami Beach, has become increasingly involved in the tech community and helped fund donations to various organizations and conferences, including Black Tech Week, Start-Up City: Miami, 500 Startups PreMoney Conference, Smart City Startups and eMerge Americas. About a year ago, he joined the AGP network, a group of angel investors, and has invested in six local startups.

He said his involvement and "brainstorming meetings" have helped shape features of the project, such as adding more community space. The plans by New York-based SHoP Architects, which new San Francisco headquarters, include a "cloud layer" - elevated public space with gardens and gathering places connecting all the towers. Also in the plans: parking lots near the I-95 exit so cars would be off the roads quickly to create a walk-bike culture, and 250- to 350-square-foot micro-unit apartments that would appeal to millenials. Nearly a third of the project - 2.4 million square feet - is earmarked for residential.

Though Simkins has already acquired the land needed, many political, legal and regulatory hurdles remain, particularly when it comes to the controversial media tower. Still, Simkins hopes to break ground next year. If that happens, he hopes to open the first buildings within three years and complete build out within seven. The developer said he is focusing first on securing a large anchor tenant. He then will move to middle-sized companies, startups, funding and support organizations in addition to 500 Startups, coworking spaces and university involvement. He's also looking at ways to activate part of the property before construction, such as locating 500 Startups there.

Yet, the Miami Innovation District is just one piece of a much larger picture of Miami as a technology hub of the Americas, Simkins says.

"It is a component that is needed, along with a lot of the other things that are already taking shape," he said. "But this provides the infrastructure ... We need the enterprise companies that will bring the employees. That will keep the talent here."

Follow Nancy Dahlberg on Twitter @ndahlberg.

PANEL DISCUSSIONMiami Innovation District developer Michael Simkins is set to appear on a Thursday lunch panel titled "What is Miami's Tech Footprint?" hosted by the Commercial Industrial Association of South Florida at Venture Hive in downtown Miami. Other panelists are Venture Hive founder Susan Amat, Pipeline founder Todd Oretsky and Peter Crovo, senior vice president of Prologis. Information: .

urn:contentItem:5W0S-W3Y1-F03R-N00X-00000-00Michael Dell: I'm The Ultimate Long-Term Investor2019-04-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:36ZLexisNexisMichael Dell: I'm The Ultimate Long-Term InvestorJacob Wolinsky

Apr 29, 2019( ValueWalk: http://www.valuewalk.com/ Delivered by Newstex) CNBC Exclusive: CNBC Excerpts: Dell Technologies Inc (NYSE:DELL) Founder and CEO Michael Dell Speaks with CNBC[1]'s Jon Fortt   https://d2wsh2n0xua73e.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/Michael-Dell.jpgImage source: CNBC Video ScreenshotWHEN: Today, Monday, April 29, 2019 WHERE: CNBC's 'Squawk Alley[2]' - at Dell Technologies World 2019 Conference in Las Vegas, NV The following is the unofficial transcript of excerpts from a CNBC EXCLUSIVE interview with Dell[3] Founder and CEO Michael Dell, and CNBC's Jon Fortt on CNBC's 'Squawk Alley' (M-F 11AM - 12PM) that aired today, Monday, April 29th. VMware CEO Pat Gelsinger also joined for part of the interview. The following is a link to video from the interview on CNBC.com: Get The Full Seth Klarman Series in PDF Get the entire 10-part series on Seth Klarman in PDF. Save it to your desktop, read it on your tablet, or email to your colleagues. Q1 hedge fund letters, conference, scoops etc[4]Dell Founder and CEO Michael Dell: I'm the ultimate long-term investor   https://player.cnbc.com/p/gZWlPC/cnbc_global?playertype=synd...uid;=7000077146...e;=640_360[5] All references must be sourced to CNBC.

CARL QUINTANILLA: Welcome back to "Squawk Alley.' Jon Fortt, as we said, is in Las Vegas today at Dell Technologies World where he sat down with Michael Dell for an exclusive interview. Jon? JON FORTT: Carl, Dell Technologies World in large part about flexibility in this cloud enterprise area. We covered a lot of ground in our conversation, Michael Dell and I. One of the things we talked about, in the broader tech landscape - investment landscape, is founder control. And we just heard from Brian Chesky[6] earlier in the show. Airbnb expected to come to market, the public markets, with dual class, at least two classes of shares and founder control. And we've got Slack, expected to do something similar. Lyft already in the market with dual class shares. Michael Dell has control in the new public iteration of Dell, makes no apologies for it. Here is what he had to say about it. MICHAEL DELL: I can only speak from my own experience. A few days before our -- the 35th birthday of our company, and that is that I think having a long-term perspective and a long-term time horizon with which, you know, one approaches the development of a company can be very helpful. And, you know, last year we had 91 billion dollars in revenues. I started the company with $1,000 in my dorm room. And it's worked out pretty well. So, I'm, you know, the ultimate long-term investor. JON FORTT: We also talked M...nd consolidation. VMware CEO Pat Gelsinger joined us. Of course, only makes sense—it's part of Dell Technologies. Dell Technologies owns 81% of VMware, though VMware's market cap is actually bigger through some kind of odd math. I asked him whether history is repeating itself in the enterprise tech cycle. We might actually see big tech companies buying other big tech companies now that the cloud is maturing. Short answer: yes. Take a listen. PAT GELSINGER: I think there is this explosion of innovation that's going on around, I call them the four super powers: cloud[7], mobility, AI and IoT. And these are just causing so many new companies, investment of capital, you know, major new IPOs that are going on. And I think with each sort of wave of these innovative cycles, there's an explosion of new companies but then there's also a consolidation of existing companies. Right? Because sort of the layers start to reform. So, up here, you've got a whole new set of them emerging in many of these areas. And in the existing areas, yeah, there is some level of consolidation. So, I do believe there will be some. Because fundamentally at the infrastructure layer, I believe customers want fewer, more strategic vendors. And as I talk to CIOs, I say, 'My job is every one of your engineers that's looking down the stack at infrastructure, I want to enable you to have them look up to the application and business differentiating services. And we're increasingly going to automate, standardize, cloud deliver those infrastructure layers, so you don't have to do it. We're doing it for you in an automated, AI standardized way. So, every one of your resources gets to look up to create business differentiating circumstances. So yes, I believe both of those will be true, consolidation and explosion of innovation. JON FORTT: Michael, assuming you agree, how long before we see that wave of massive consolidation? Not again just big companies buying small companies, but big companies buying big companies. Three years, five years? MICHAEL DELL: Well, certainly the combination of Dell EMC VMware - PAT GELSINGER: It is pretty big. MICHAEL DELL: -- was the biggest one yet to date. So, that was a pretty big one. And last year we added more than $11 billion in revenue, so that was some additional industry consolidation there for you. You know, look, I think customers, to Pat's point, have told us very clearly, they don't want to be systems integrators anymore. And they are looking for fewer partners. And bringing together a broad sense of capabilities across the infrastructure, security, client devices, the cloud, digital transformation, you know, enabling all those capabilities for customers, they would much rather work with one leading company than 20 or 30 smaller ones. JON FORTT: And this is a key theme for investors to really zero in on. Think about it, we heard it from Satya Nadella[8] at Microsoft and the way they're trying to work with enterprises to bring their legacy systems into the cloud. We've heard it from Ginni Rommety at IBM. Look, they're trying to gobble down Red Hat. That should close in the second half of the year. I also talked to Michael Dell about VMware. He's trying to make the case for VMware as kind of a lingua franca of the cloud era allowing companies to move their workloads, their data back and forth between the public cloud, private cloud, under this hybrid model. He says that's important. Take a listen. MICHAEL DELL: I think if you look at the rise of Kubernetes, you see clearly customers want to have an ability to move workloads around, not only among all the public clouds but into their own data centers, and into colos, and you know, out to the edge. And, you know, customers are concerned about sending all their data away to somebody else and then rendering it back. And so - JON FORTT: Not because of security but because of performance and convenience? MICHAEL DELL: I think it's going to be performance, cost, regulatory concerns, you know, latency for sure. So, a variety of concerns won't dictate that all your data and all your applications will end up in one place. The debate is over, Jon. It's no longer is it the private cloud or is it the public cloud? It's both. JON FORTT: And that's the story of the next three years that investors are going to be paying attention to. Can Amazon[9] adjust to -- not just Amazon, say Google, adjust to that legacy enterprise reality of holding customers' hands through regulatory issues, all of that, can they get that together faster than the likes of Dell and others, can move into the cloud era with flexibility, new technology and keep those enterprise customers. The battle is on from so many different directions in tech and that's a big theme here at Dell Technologies World that makes for a lot of competition and interesting alliances, guys.
