So the tech sector bounced back on Thursday. That’s a pity. The higher and longer the boom, the more who get sucked up in it. It had seemed September was bringing a smidgeon of sense to the momentum mania that propelled “tech” stocks here and elsewhere to record highs in August, prices so high that they dragged the overall S&P500 index with them. And it still might be – dead cat bounces are to be expected as a bubble bursts – or the fever could continue. It’s not possible to predict irrational behaviour, other than to know at some stage it will unravel. While the headlines have been full of the American tech sector’s dizzying surge, it was a surprise for me to see that Australia’s fledgling tech index was the world’s best performed by a very long way since the March COVID bottom. As the Ophir Asset Management co-founders Andrew Mitchell and Stephen Ng explained in their latest newsletter covering last month: “Much of this can be attributed to Afterpay rising a staggering +927% over this period; though Nearmap (+250%), Codan (+176%), EML Payments (155%), Megaport (+151%), Data#3 (+137%) and Wisetech (+135%), Appen (+99%) and NextDC (+75%) have shown the Australian IT market is not a one-trick pony during the market recovery.” Well, maybe not one trick, but heavily reliant on the Afterpay game. At Thursday’s close of $75.63 a share, it has dropped 21 per cent from its $95.97 August high – but still has a market capitalisation of $21.5 billion. That’s, um, pretty amazing for a company that lost $23 million in the past financial year and had EBITDA (earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation) of just $44 million. The share price is based on momentum – it’s going up because it’s going up – and the blue sky potential of the company rolling out its consumer finance product unimpeded. The share price is based on momentum – it’s going up because it’s going up – and the blue sky potential of the company rolling out its consumer finance product unimpeded. (Since I last mentioned Afterpay in these pages , NAB has launched a no-interest, no-fee credit card aimed squarely at Afterpay’s target market, an indication of competition to come. And ahead, when the Reserve Bank resumes normal work, is the likelihood of merchants being allowed to pass on the high fees Afterpay charges them. At present, in something rather like retail price maintenance, merchants are forbidden to do so.) But Australia’s little tech sector doesn’t add up to a hill of beans in this crazy world, also known as the US market where Apple’s market cap last month was greater than the entire value of the FTSE 100 – the largest 100 UK companies. British market veteran and commentator Anthony Peters has been watching the tech show with all the scepticism of those who have seen these sorts of movies before, albeit always with acknowledgement of the John Maynard Keynes quote: “Markets can stay irrational longer than you can stay solvent.” Ahead of Wednesday night’s bounce, Mr Peters observed: “On August 19th Apple broke through the $US2 trillion market cap. Since then it has handed back $US325 billion or, looked at a different way, the equivalent of the sum total of its projected 2021 revenues or one and a half times the market cap of the newly anointed Dow component Salesforce. “This is a great time for playing with silly numbers. The Big Six were collectively worth around $US5 trillion at the beginning of the year. At their peak a week ago today that number had risen to $US8.2 trillion. As at close of business last night that figure had shrunk to $US7.1 trillion. “So even after the great September swoon they are still worth over $US2 trillion more than they had been at New Year. “Optimists see an overdue correction and a probable buying opportunity. Pessimists smell blood and the beginning of the end for the great countercyclical stock bubble. One of them might be right.” And then there’s Tesla, for which Mr Peters has what you might call a special regard: “Meanwhile Tesla, the bedroom-bound, top-knot sporting geek’s favourite toy, took a 21.06% – not joking – hit yesterday to close down $US88.11 at $U330.21. On Tuesday the stock had closed at $US502.49. “That said, a year ago you could have bought it at just over $US43 so who’s the fool? “At the time of writing it had dropped further to $US324.15.’’ Entrepreneur Elon Musk used his SpaceX rocket to launch his Tesla on a course to Mars. Photo: AAP/SpaceX Among the stunts pulled by Tesla founder Elon Musk has been sending one of his cars (minus the expensive heavy bits) into orbit around Mars. Tesla’s share price has departed further from the company’s expected earnings than that car has from Earth. It is simply not possible to imagine Tesla earning enough profit in a reasonable lifetime to repay the top prices for its shares. That’s the way capitalism was supposed to work – companies earned profits to reward shareholders for taking equity – but that goes out the window when the game is on. The game is called “the greater fool”. Tesla is not like the Big Six tech giants, the FAANGM made up of Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google and Microsoft. Unlike many of the Dot.Bomb stars, they are big companies with real businesses and big profits , albeit in the case of Netflix helped by some generous accounting. (Tesla surprised the market by actually reporting profit in the latest quarter – $US104 million – when a loss was expected. But that profit was on sales of $US6 billion and thanks to regulatory credits. Its market cap is “only” $US341 billion. The price/earnings ratio is too ridiculous to bother calculating.) Aside from momentum, the greater fool game and money being as good as free while central banks are running the printing presses hard, the justification for buying Big Tech is that it is supposed to be less subject to the economic damage caused by the pandemic. As Gavekal Research summarised it: “With millions working from home, forced to seek their entertainment from the sofa and obliged to do their shopping over the internet, Big Tech has been the big winner from COVID-19. “In a world where the biggest fear of investors is that policymakers will decide once again to lock down entire populations, the stocks of Big Tech (and health care) are the obvious anti-fragile assets of choice.” On the other hand, Big Tech is priced to perfection. Like our little Afterpay, it is possible to imagine regulatory hurdles down the track. No, not like the Australian government’s attempted heist, as Crikey’s Bernard Keane has described the plan to steal money primarily for the benefit of News Corp and Nine Entertainment , but first by a co-ordinated international effort to tax them fairly and, secondly, by reinserting fangs into US anti-trust law and enforcement. Both are a way off – they would require a responsible US government to start with – but they are closer than Mars. In the meantime, there’s the game. A worry is that there are many rookies playing along at home – people with little or no market experience who think trading is easy, based on their experience since the March low. That hasn’t been the real world.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF MFP INVESTORS LLC, TALKS ABOUT INVESTMENT AND M&A ON BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

DECEMBER 2, 2010

SPEAKERS: MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

12:01

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE: Michael Price joining us now of MFP Investors. Is legendary too much of a -

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC: Yes.

KEENE: - should I not say legendary?

PRICE: So are you.

KEENE: Good to see you.

PRICE: Good to see you.

KEENE: Let's just start with the state of value investing. When you wake up in the morning, is there a lot of value out there or was that so 2009?

PRICE: There are pockets. There are pockets. Yesterday we had a big day, so, you know, it closed that gap. But, yes, we are finding some things to do. When you see mergers announced at 40 percent premiums to where stocks are trading like Del Monte, Baldor Electric, right?

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: It tells you there is still value out there.

KEENE: And the mergers it just seems to pick up. In talking to Jonathan Keehner on our M&A team, they are enthused about having fun in 2011. Does it just keep rolling here with an economic recovery?

PRICE: It keeps rolling until some investment bank puts up a bridge loan and they cannot place it. Then all of a sudden it grinds to a halt. It starts rolling until there is a problem in -

KEENE: Okay. Let's -

PRICE: So some of these are being announced with bridge loans.

KEENE: Yes, let's look at the "dreaded first chart" here. Michael Price with us here. This is Jason Trennert's chart from Strategas. I'll steal from anyone, Michael. This is a Jason chart. This is the Nasdaq 100 to the S&P 500, growth back in vogue. Do you find value in what you and I perceive is value? Or do you find value in growth?

PRICE: Both. You know, we are long some growthy kind of stocks.

KEENE: Give me some examples.

PRICE: We're long some e-Bay. And if you back out the cash, you back out their value in Skype, and you look at the two parts of e-Bay, I mean you can make an argument that it is pretty cheap and that is a growthy stock.

KEENE: Casey, make up an e-Bay chart going back at least 15 years, 20 years, whatever. Just see what you can do with that.

Look at this chart. This is great. Emily, thanks for bringing this up.

PRICE: 3PAR, 3PAR up.

KEENE: Were you an owner?

PRICE: No, hold on. We own a comparable -

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: - that is actually privately owned ConneXium. 3PAR is in the storage business, and Compellent, Epsilon, and 3PAR were taken over at huge numbers - Compellent not yet, but it probably will be - at seven times, ten times revenues.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: Fifty, 60 times earnings. Crazy numbers. By guys like EMC, Joe Tucci, and others who really don't care. Another billion here or there doesn't really matter to them.

KEENE: Yes, that's the way I am.

PRICE: But, you know, the valuations are crazy.

KEENE: And you look at 3PAR, and the reason I put this up, look at this chart. I had to get my bow tie straight.

PRICE: Well, we're very well aware of it.

KEENE: I wore this red - this is a Red Sox bow tie.

PRICE: I wore my Yankee -

KEENE: You wore your Yankee - that's good. You wore - did you see that? I have the dumb red bow tie. You've got - put that ring up again, let's look at that. Get in here for a close up. I'm proud that you're wearing that ring.

PRICE: (Inaudible) it's about to sign (inaudible).

KEENE: What's Jeter doing?

PRICE: Derek Jeter.

KEENE: What's he going to do?

PRICE: Well, I understand that he has got a very fair offer on the table.

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: So it should be taken. But we'll see -

KEENE: Well, let's - back to 3PAR. Back to investment. Over on the right side of this chart is the game theory here involved, where two players, three players get involved. When you are a value owner, that is your dream.

PRICE: That's the dream. You have a bid for a company. If someone else came into Del Monte because of the pet food business, which is the key, you know, off to the races. If someone comes in - Boone Pickens as a part Exco with a group -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - if someone else shows up, it is off to the races.

KEENE: And what you do, you are known for careful analysis, not just going in quickly, careful analysis.

PRICE: We do a little work.

KEENE: Do you look at the strategic -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - selections down the road, the companies that would come in?

PRICE: Absolutely. Strategic is better than financial, right? You want a strategic buyer. The ABB bid for Baldor, which owns Reliance Electric, is strategic. They market together. They will promote together. They manufacture together. That is strategic. That is a better buyer than a KKR.

KEENE: Let's look at a disaster - M&A sale Alcatel-Lucent. This has been a train wreck since time began. I'm going -

PRICE: It still is.

KEENE: - to be polite and not ask if you own this dog up there.

PRICE: No, we were never involved.

KEENE: But how does this happen?

PRICE: I cannot help you there. We were not involved.

KEENE: You were not involved, but when you look at dinosaurs mating as some would say, but in my language a lot of people have written about this.

PRICE: Yes, but out of Alcatel-Lucent, we will get involved when they spin something off that is going to be too cheap. So these companies reinvent themselves numerous ways, and Wall Street stands in there to make markets and new securities.

You know, we have spin offs every day. We had an IPO today of something called FXCM that came out of the Refco bankruptcy. I mean that was an interesting situation, a currency trading firm.

KEENE: Which sector is the most attractive right now? Everybody is telling me technology, technology, technology. Where are you?

PRICE: Well, tech is interesting. We are not big tech players. I think natural gas is pretty interesting. Between the shale plays and regular gas producers, gas has lagged oil quite a bit.

KEENE: Where will the market in general go next year?

PRICE: Stocks? I have no idea.

KEENE: You don't really care, do you?

PRICE: I don't like the bond market.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And gold is a bubble, and I don't like the ten year. But stocks in general are reasonable here. I think there are a few pockets of cheapness, but here and there they are where they should be.

KEENE: Michael Price with us, folks. We're going to come back and continue our discussion with Mr. Price about M&A into next year.

12:06

(BREAK)

12:10

KEENE: Michael Price with me. He has been bragging about his New York Yankees World Series Championship, King of the World ring. Thank you for bringing that in.

Wheat - here's an exogenous event. Wheat surges on drought. Do you just stay focused on 20 or 40 or 50 stocks, or do you care about the stuff I babble about all day?

PRICE: No, we don't do the macro, but we look at hundreds of stocks. A lot more than 20 or 40.

KEENE: Global macro seems to be the vogue now -

PRICE: Yes, but that's not what we do.

KEENE: - with hedge fund resisting.

PRICE: That's not what we do.

KEENE: Is it global macro is right, and then they get it wrong and everybody goes back to playing (inaudible), classic long/short.

PRICE: Yes, I'm excited in that they are global. They are going away from the U.S. market. Let them go into Brazil. That gives me more things to do here, less competition I think. Let them get distracted.

KEENE: Talk about the American malaise, the idea that America is not doing that well and that you see this wall of worry, recovery in equities.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: And, you know -

PRICE: It is last spring and summer. I mean it was everybody was so skeptical and yet you have this fantastic economy that is slowly churning ahead. The car loadings at Berkshire Hathaway, Burlington Northern reported were very impressive.

KEENE: Phenomenal, yes.

PRICE: The truck tons that they report are very impressive. The economy is churning around.

KEENE: Emily, go the Goldman Sachs note, please, if you would. This is the "note of the day." And we're going to go to the note of the day here, folks, we rip up the script. We do that all the time. Drives them nuts in the control room. Goldman Sachs global research, this is Jim O'Neill's former desk, room to grow. We expect the most significant shift to take place in the U.S. Four percent 2012.

PRICE: But it is the valuations. You know, here you can buy at low teens multiples terrific U.S. worldwide and U.S. companies participate in it with better regulation I think here than around the world. So I think it is not only better, but cheaper here.

KEENE: Let's keep Goldman Sachs up here just because we brought up the note. Here is the stock. Is big Wall Street going to lead the way? Or do you -

PRICE: I think it is so interesting.

KEENE: - believe the boutiques are going to do it?

PRICE: I am going to tell you I think some boutiques are set up very well. The Greenhills of the world are terrific. They are focused.

Other boutiques have conflicts. You know, Cowen runs something called Ramius. Cowen is trying to get investment banking business at the same time Ramius is doing hostile 13Ds against some of the companies. It doesn't make sense.

Goldman should split up into three parts. They should have money management, trading, and investment banking. Investment banking requires little or no equity. Money management little or no equity. They plow some equity into the trading business -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - and spin off the big dividend.

KEENE: Okay, this is very explicit right here. This is important. We're going to stay on this. Forget about the rest of the stuff. Goldman Sachs, let's start again.

PRICE: We own the stock.

KEENE: Should they be - you own the stock.

PRICE: We own the stock. The stock -

KEENE: There's the chart up here, folks.

PRICE: The stock is reasonably priced. It is a terrific business, okay? And I remember watching Fidelity, the big mutual fund company, back when everything went well for them in the eighties and nineties, got too big. And I said to them why don't you split up into three, four parts. A bond fund, equity, this and that.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: They never did and they kind of languished in the last ten years.

KEENE: Did you go long the day of the testimony?

PRICE: We traded in the stock, yes.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: When you look at Goldman Sachs, the first step is should they stay a bank or do they go - do they leave the banking number all over government.

PRICE: I think they should become three entities which requires one being a bank. You know, the trading - they have a trading business. They have a banking business and a money management business. They do not have to be together. They can free up capital. They can get higher valuations. I think the stock would be $250 if they did that.

KEENE: Let's go back to the little banks. You mentioned Greenhill before. I think of Evercore, what Altman is doing there.

PRICE: Another one.

KEENE: There is an independence there. Are they getting the smartest people?

PRICE: Some of them are getting very good people, sure. Cowen has been hiring good people. And buried inside of the biggest bank - Bank of America - is Merrill. When they start hitting on all cylinders, getting past the mortgage put back mess, Bank of America is a powerful franchise.

KEENE: Is Morgan -

PRICE: And people forget that they own Merrill -

KEENE: Is Morgan Stanley strapped because of all these broker deal mortgages?

PRICE: Yes, Morgan Stanley has got other issues, sure they do.

KEENE: They've got other issues.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: Let's go back here. Could you bring up e-Bay, Emily? I know we are throwing it around here with Michael Price, but let's bring up e-Bay. I am surprised you mentioned this name. They're working on it back in the control room. They've got to get the gerbil going to bring it up.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: There it is. They fed the gerbil, good.

Okay, e-Bay back a decade, I'm going to be blunt. IPO up it goes.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: Stupid price, and it has gone nowhere. Is that a safe summary?

PRICE: Well, it has gone from $12 to $29.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And at $12 bucks where we kind of got involved - $12 and $15 I think it was, I mean we were paying under ten times earnings for their basic business, getting other stuff for free. They did not go sell a slug of the Skype.

And their Paypal business is going to be probably one of the most valuable businesses going forward. Everybody wants to get into electronic trunk funds transfer -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - secure electronic funds transfer.

KEENE: Well -

PRICE: VeriFone is doing it. VeriFone stock has been a rocket this year. It will continue to go. e-Bay I think is really interesting.

KEENE: Sheila Dharmarajan was out here the other night - yesterday, rather, talking up NetFlix. When you see the silliness of NetFlix, can you distill that down? Is it a profit model you can stay with?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: You have not looked at it?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: When you looked at e-Bay I thought maybe you'd look at -

PRICE: That was -

KEENE: Give me another name. What else are you looking at besides e- Bay?

PRICE: Well, we own some big industrials. You know, we still own our Ingersoll Rand, which I like a lot.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: We do some other parts today. It is getting pretty full, but if you have some growth going forward, it is a cheap stock. The balance sheet has gotten much better as they have paid down debt.

KEENE: I see Emerson Electric with 57 percent global. It is amazing these industrials how they have gone global.

PRICE: And you can get a big currency benefit, too.

KEENE: Let's look at Colgate Palmolive here. I want to talk to Michael Price about investing 101 here. We're going to bring up Colgate, which is has just done great for ten and 12 years.

Not your kind of stock, but this goes back to the people that aren't Michael Price. How do you know when to sell? Or do you just go with buy and hold if you not as sophisticated?

PRICE: Selling is much tougher. You know, I think you buy things when things are 30 or 40 percent below what you think the asset value is. Selling it is very hard to tell. So we tend to dribble them out slowly as they move up.

KEENE: As they move up -

PRICE: I don't know the valuation of Colgate so I cannot help you there.

KEENE: No, I understand the valuation of Colgate. I just brought it up with this, you know, buy and hold strategy. We are seeing so many individual investors really looking at dividend reinvestment as an important way to go.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: I mean you don't care about that. It is much more strategic.

PRICE: There are some large cap - Microsoft is one, IBM is one, Johnson & Johnson - where good investors have made the arguments that these are very cheap, 12, 13 times earnings, with a dividend yield of three or four percent. And they are right. They are basically right. These stocks are pretty cheap looking over a decade.

KEENE: When you look at this, what is your single message for 2011?

PRICE: I think you have to be constructive. I think you have to look at - you know, that this economy is going to do better even in spite of somewhat higher interest rates.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: You are going to churn ahead and I think you will find opportunities, so you have got to pay attention.

KEENE: I want to talk another sector. You mentioned the U.S. field, you are not looking abroad.

PRICE: No.

KEENE: You are using the U.S. component -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - placed abroad. When you look at the dollar filtering in there, that has got to benefit some people here almost either way. I mean the U.S. is doing better than Europe, aren't they?

PRICE: Yes, the U.S. is going to do better. I think the problems in Europe are the PIIGS and they may be spreading a little bit. You know, we have that further out, so I think the focus will be on them first hurting the euro. And then unfortunately helping the dollar, which won't be that good in the short term.

KEENE: Humility is a big part of this. What is the biggest mistake you have made? I don't mean like the specific story, but philosophically in investment what is the thing that got you into the most hot water?

PRICE: Oh, probably getting into large positions where you really cannot exit. You know -

KEENE: Too big a position.

PRICE: - you are the lead guy and, yes, I mean -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - Sunbeam Oster comes to mind from way back.

KEENE: Show me that ring again. We've got to get one more look at this, Victor. Get in. Move the coffee cup. Victor, bring it right in here. Look - look at that. That is amazing.

PRICE: That's the 27th one the Yankees have given out to players.

KEENE: I've got my Mickey Mantle belt buckle on, but -

PRICE: There you go. Now we're talking.

KEENE: - I'm not going to show it right here. A Mickey Mantle belt buckle, I saw him steal second base once at Fenway Park. That was great.

We've got to go. Michael Price, thank you so much.

12:18

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF MFP INVESTORS LLC, TALKS ABOUT INVESTMENT AND M&A ON BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

DECEMBER 2, 2010

SPEAKERS: MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

12:01

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE: Michael Price joining us now of MFP Investors. Is legendary too much of a -

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC: Yes.

KEENE: - should I not say legendary?

PRICE: So are you.

KEENE: Good to see you.

PRICE: Good to see you.

KEENE: Let's just start with the state of value investing. When you wake up in the morning, is there a lot of value out there or was that so 2009?

PRICE: There are pockets. There are pockets. Yesterday we had a big day, so, you know, it closed that gap. But, yes, we are finding some things to do. When you see mergers announced at 40 percent premiums to where stocks are trading like Del Monte, Baldor Electric, right?

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: It tells you there is still value out there.

KEENE: And the mergers it just seems to pick up. In talking to Jonathan Keehner on our M&A team, they are enthused about having fun in 2011. Does it just keep rolling here with an economic recovery?

PRICE: It keeps rolling until some investment bank puts up a bridge loan and they cannot place it. Then all of a sudden it grinds to a halt. It starts rolling until there is a problem in -

KEENE: Okay. Let's -

PRICE: So some of these are being announced with bridge loans.

KEENE: Yes, let's look at the "dreaded first chart" here. Michael Price with us here. This is Jason Trennert's chart from Strategas. I'll steal from anyone, Michael. This is a Jason chart. This is the Nasdaq 100 to the S&P 500, growth back in vogue. Do you find value in what you and I perceive is value? Or do you find value in growth?

PRICE: Both. You know, we are long some growthy kind of stocks.

KEENE: Give me some examples.

PRICE: We're long some e-Bay. And if you back out the cash, you back out their value in Skype, and you look at the two parts of e-Bay, I mean you can make an argument that it is pretty cheap and that is a growthy stock.

KEENE: Casey, make up an e-Bay chart going back at least 15 years, 20 years, whatever. Just see what you can do with that.

Look at this chart. This is great. Emily, thanks for bringing this up.

PRICE: 3PAR, 3PAR up.

KEENE: Were you an owner?

PRICE: No, hold on. We own a comparable -

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: - that is actually privately owned ConneXium. 3PAR is in the storage business, and Compellent, Epsilon, and 3PAR were taken over at huge numbers - Compellent not yet, but it probably will be - at seven times, ten times revenues.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: Fifty, 60 times earnings. Crazy numbers. By guys like EMC, Joe Tucci, and others who really don't care. Another billion here or there doesn't really matter to them.

KEENE: Yes, that's the way I am.

PRICE: But, you know, the valuations are crazy.

KEENE: And you look at 3PAR, and the reason I put this up, look at this chart. I had to get my bow tie straight.

PRICE: Well, we're very well aware of it.

KEENE: I wore this red - this is a Red Sox bow tie.

PRICE: I wore my Yankee -

KEENE: You wore your Yankee - that's good. You wore - did you see that? I have the dumb red bow tie. You've got - put that ring up again, let's look at that. Get in here for a close up. I'm proud that you're wearing that ring.

PRICE: (Inaudible) it's about to sign (inaudible).

KEENE: What's Jeter doing?

PRICE: Derek Jeter.

KEENE: What's he going to do?

PRICE: Well, I understand that he has got a very fair offer on the table.

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: So it should be taken. But we'll see -

KEENE: Well, let's - back to 3PAR. Back to investment. Over on the right side of this chart is the game theory here involved, where two players, three players get involved. When you are a value owner, that is your dream.

PRICE: That's the dream. You have a bid for a company. If someone else came into Del Monte because of the pet food business, which is the key, you know, off to the races. If someone comes in - Boone Pickens as a part Exco with a group -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - if someone else shows up, it is off to the races.

KEENE: And what you do, you are known for careful analysis, not just going in quickly, careful analysis.

PRICE: We do a little work.

KEENE: Do you look at the strategic -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - selections down the road, the companies that would come in?

PRICE: Absolutely. Strategic is better than financial, right? You want a strategic buyer. The ABB bid for Baldor, which owns Reliance Electric, is strategic. They market together. They will promote together. They manufacture together. That is strategic. That is a better buyer than a KKR.

KEENE: Let's look at a disaster - M&A sale Alcatel-Lucent. This has been a train wreck since time began. I'm going -

PRICE: It still is.

KEENE: - to be polite and not ask if you own this dog up there.

PRICE: No, we were never involved.

KEENE: But how does this happen?

PRICE: I cannot help you there. We were not involved.

KEENE: You were not involved, but when you look at dinosaurs mating as some would say, but in my language a lot of people have written about this.

PRICE: Yes, but out of Alcatel-Lucent, we will get involved when they spin something off that is going to be too cheap. So these companies reinvent themselves numerous ways, and Wall Street stands in there to make markets and new securities.

You know, we have spin offs every day. We had an IPO today of something called FXCM that came out of the Refco bankruptcy. I mean that was an interesting situation, a currency trading firm.

KEENE: Which sector is the most attractive right now? Everybody is telling me technology, technology, technology. Where are you?

PRICE: Well, tech is interesting. We are not big tech players. I think natural gas is pretty interesting. Between the shale plays and regular gas producers, gas has lagged oil quite a bit.

KEENE: Where will the market in general go next year?

PRICE: Stocks? I have no idea.

KEENE: You don't really care, do you?

PRICE: I don't like the bond market.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And gold is a bubble, and I don't like the ten year. But stocks in general are reasonable here. I think there are a few pockets of cheapness, but here and there they are where they should be.

KEENE: Michael Price with us, folks. We're going to come back and continue our discussion with Mr. Price about M&A into next year.

12:06

(BREAK)

12:10

KEENE: Michael Price with me. He has been bragging about his New York Yankees World Series Championship, King of the World ring. Thank you for bringing that in.

Wheat - here's an exogenous event. Wheat surges on drought. Do you just stay focused on 20 or 40 or 50 stocks, or do you care about the stuff I babble about all day?

PRICE: No, we don't do the macro, but we look at hundreds of stocks. A lot more than 20 or 40.

KEENE: Global macro seems to be the vogue now -

PRICE: Yes, but that's not what we do.

KEENE: - with hedge fund resisting.

PRICE: That's not what we do.

KEENE: Is it global macro is right, and then they get it wrong and everybody goes back to playing (inaudible), classic long/short.

PRICE: Yes, I'm excited in that they are global. They are going away from the U.S. market. Let them go into Brazil. That gives me more things to do here, less competition I think. Let them get distracted.

KEENE: Talk about the American malaise, the idea that America is not doing that well and that you see this wall of worry, recovery in equities.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: And, you know -

PRICE: It is last spring and summer. I mean it was everybody was so skeptical and yet you have this fantastic economy that is slowly churning ahead. The car loadings at Berkshire Hathaway, Burlington Northern reported were very impressive.

KEENE: Phenomenal, yes.

PRICE: The truck tons that they report are very impressive. The economy is churning around.

KEENE: Emily, go the Goldman Sachs note, please, if you would. This is the "note of the day." And we're going to go to the note of the day here, folks, we rip up the script. We do that all the time. Drives them nuts in the control room. Goldman Sachs global research, this is Jim O'Neill's former desk, room to grow. We expect the most significant shift to take place in the U.S. Four percent 2012.

PRICE: But it is the valuations. You know, here you can buy at low teens multiples terrific U.S. worldwide and U.S. companies participate in it with better regulation I think here than around the world. So I think it is not only better, but cheaper here.

KEENE: Let's keep Goldman Sachs up here just because we brought up the note. Here is the stock. Is big Wall Street going to lead the way? Or do you -

PRICE: I think it is so interesting.

KEENE: - believe the boutiques are going to do it?

PRICE: I am going to tell you I think some boutiques are set up very well. The Greenhills of the world are terrific. They are focused.

Other boutiques have conflicts. You know, Cowen runs something called Ramius. Cowen is trying to get investment banking business at the same time Ramius is doing hostile 13Ds against some of the companies. It doesn't make sense.

Goldman should split up into three parts. They should have money management, trading, and investment banking. Investment banking requires little or no equity. Money management little or no equity. They plow some equity into the trading business -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - and spin off the big dividend.

KEENE: Okay, this is very explicit right here. This is important. We're going to stay on this. Forget about the rest of the stuff. Goldman Sachs, let's start again.

PRICE: We own the stock.

KEENE: Should they be - you own the stock.

PRICE: We own the stock. The stock -

KEENE: There's the chart up here, folks.

PRICE: The stock is reasonably priced. It is a terrific business, okay? And I remember watching Fidelity, the big mutual fund company, back when everything went well for them in the eighties and nineties, got too big. And I said to them why don't you split up into three, four parts. A bond fund, equity, this and that.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: They never did and they kind of languished in the last ten years.

KEENE: Did you go long the day of the testimony?

PRICE: We traded in the stock, yes.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: When you look at Goldman Sachs, the first step is should they stay a bank or do they go - do they leave the banking number all over government.

PRICE: I think they should become three entities which requires one being a bank. You know, the trading - they have a trading business. They have a banking business and a money management business. They do not have to be together. They can free up capital. They can get higher valuations. I think the stock would be $250 if they did that.

KEENE: Let's go back to the little banks. You mentioned Greenhill before. I think of Evercore, what Altman is doing there.

PRICE: Another one.

KEENE: There is an independence there. Are they getting the smartest people?

PRICE: Some of them are getting very good people, sure. Cowen has been hiring good people. And buried inside of the biggest bank - Bank of America - is Merrill. When they start hitting on all cylinders, getting past the mortgage put back mess, Bank of America is a powerful franchise.

KEENE: Is Morgan -

PRICE: And people forget that they own Merrill -

KEENE: Is Morgan Stanley strapped because of all these broker deal mortgages?

PRICE: Yes, Morgan Stanley has got other issues, sure they do.

KEENE: They've got other issues.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: Let's go back here. Could you bring up e-Bay, Emily? I know we are throwing it around here with Michael Price, but let's bring up e-Bay. I am surprised you mentioned this name. They're working on it back in the control room. They've got to get the gerbil going to bring it up.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: There it is. They fed the gerbil, good.

Okay, e-Bay back a decade, I'm going to be blunt. IPO up it goes.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: Stupid price, and it has gone nowhere. Is that a safe summary?

PRICE: Well, it has gone from $12 to $29.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And at $12 bucks where we kind of got involved - $12 and $15 I think it was, I mean we were paying under ten times earnings for their basic business, getting other stuff for free. They did not go sell a slug of the Skype.

And their Paypal business is going to be probably one of the most valuable businesses going forward. Everybody wants to get into electronic trunk funds transfer -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - secure electronic funds transfer.

KEENE: Well -

PRICE: VeriFone is doing it. VeriFone stock has been a rocket this year. It will continue to go. e-Bay I think is really interesting.

KEENE: Sheila Dharmarajan was out here the other night - yesterday, rather, talking up NetFlix. When you see the silliness of NetFlix, can you distill that down? Is it a profit model you can stay with?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: You have not looked at it?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: When you looked at e-Bay I thought maybe you'd look at -

PRICE: That was -

KEENE: Give me another name. What else are you looking at besides e- Bay?

PRICE: Well, we own some big industrials. You know, we still own our Ingersoll Rand, which I like a lot.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: We do some other parts today. It is getting pretty full, but if you have some growth going forward, it is a cheap stock. The balance sheet has gotten much better as they have paid down debt.

KEENE: I see Emerson Electric with 57 percent global. It is amazing these industrials how they have gone global.

PRICE: And you can get a big currency benefit, too.

KEENE: Let's look at Colgate Palmolive here. I want to talk to Michael Price about investing 101 here. We're going to bring up Colgate, which is has just done great for ten and 12 years.

Not your kind of stock, but this goes back to the people that aren't Michael Price. How do you know when to sell? Or do you just go with buy and hold if you not as sophisticated?

PRICE: Selling is much tougher. You know, I think you buy things when things are 30 or 40 percent below what you think the asset value is. Selling it is very hard to tell. So we tend to dribble them out slowly as they move up.

KEENE: As they move up -

PRICE: I don't know the valuation of Colgate so I cannot help you there.

KEENE: No, I understand the valuation of Colgate. I just brought it up with this, you know, buy and hold strategy. We are seeing so many individual investors really looking at dividend reinvestment as an important way to go.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: I mean you don't care about that. It is much more strategic.

PRICE: There are some large cap - Microsoft is one, IBM is one, Johnson & Johnson - where good investors have made the arguments that these are very cheap, 12, 13 times earnings, with a dividend yield of three or four percent. And they are right. They are basically right. These stocks are pretty cheap looking over a decade.

KEENE: When you look at this, what is your single message for 2011?

PRICE: I think you have to be constructive. I think you have to look at - you know, that this economy is going to do better even in spite of somewhat higher interest rates.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: You are going to churn ahead and I think you will find opportunities, so you have got to pay attention.

KEENE: I want to talk another sector. You mentioned the U.S. field, you are not looking abroad.

PRICE: No.

KEENE: You are using the U.S. component -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - placed abroad. When you look at the dollar filtering in there, that has got to benefit some people here almost either way. I mean the U.S. is doing better than Europe, aren't they?

PRICE: Yes, the U.S. is going to do better. I think the problems in Europe are the PIIGS and they may be spreading a little bit. You know, we have that further out, so I think the focus will be on them first hurting the euro. And then unfortunately helping the dollar, which won't be that good in the short term.

KEENE: Humility is a big part of this. What is the biggest mistake you have made? I don't mean like the specific story, but philosophically in investment what is the thing that got you into the most hot water?

PRICE: Oh, probably getting into large positions where you really cannot exit. You know -

KEENE: Too big a position.

PRICE: - you are the lead guy and, yes, I mean -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - Sunbeam Oster comes to mind from way back.

KEENE: Show me that ring again. We've got to get one more look at this, Victor. Get in. Move the coffee cup. Victor, bring it right in here. Look - look at that. That is amazing.

PRICE: That's the 27th one the Yankees have given out to players.

KEENE: I've got my Mickey Mantle belt buckle on, but -

PRICE: There you go. Now we're talking.

KEENE: - I'm not going to show it right here. A Mickey Mantle belt buckle, I saw him steal second base once at Fenway Park. That was great.

We've got to go. Michael Price, thank you so much.

12:18

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

PRICE: Well, we own some big industrials. You know, we still own our Ingersoll Rand, which I like a lot.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: We do some other parts today. It is getting pretty full, but if you have some growth going forward, it is a cheap stock. The balance sheet has gotten much better as they have paid down debt.

KEENE: I see Emerson Electric with 57 percent global. It is amazing these industrials how they have gone global.

PRICE: And you can get a big currency benefit, too.

KEENE: Let's look at Colgate Palmolive here. I want to talk to Michael Price about investing 101 here. We're going to bring up Colgate, which is has just done great for ten and 12 years.

Not your kind of stock, but this goes back to the people that aren't Michael Price. How do you know when to sell? Or do you just go with buy and hold if you not as sophisticated?

PRICE: Selling is much tougher. You know, I think you buy things when things are 30 or 40 percent below what you think the asset value is. Selling it is very hard to tell. So we tend to dribble them out slowly as they move up.

KEENE: As they move up -

PRICE: I don't know the valuation of Colgate so I cannot help you there.

KEENE: No, I understand the valuation of Colgate. I just brought it up with this, you know, buy and hold strategy. We are seeing so many individual investors really looking at dividend reinvestment as an important way to go.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: I mean you don't care about that. It is much more strategic.

PRICE: There are some large cap - Microsoft is one, IBM is one, Johnson & Johnson - where good investors have made the arguments that these are very cheap, 12, 13 times earnings, with a dividend yield of three or four percent. And they are right. They are basically right. These stocks are pretty cheap looking over a decade.

KEENE: When you look at this, what is your single message for 2011?

PRICE: I think you have to be constructive. I think you have to look at - you know, that this economy is going to do better even in spite of somewhat higher interest rates.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: You are going to churn ahead and I think you will find opportunities, so you have got to pay attention.

KEENE: I want to talk another sector. You mentioned the U.S. field, you are not looking abroad.

PRICE: No.

KEENE: You are using the U.S. component -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - placed abroad. When you look at the dollar filtering in there, that has got to benefit some people here almost either way. I mean the U.S. is doing better than Europe, aren't they?

PRICE: Yes, the U.S. is going to do better. I think the problems in Europe are the PIIGS and they may be spreading a little bit. You know, we have that further out, so I think the focus will be on them first hurting the euro. And then unfortunately helping the dollar, which won't be that good in the short term.

KEENE: Humility is a big part of this. What is the biggest mistake you have made? I don't mean like the specific story, but philosophically in investment what is the thing that got you into the most hot water?

PRICE: Oh, probably getting into large positions where you really cannot exit. You know -

KEENE: Too big a position.

PRICE: - you are the lead guy and, yes, I mean -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - Sunbeam Oster comes to mind from way back.

KEENE: Show me that ring again. We've got to get one more look at this, Victor. Get in. Move the coffee cup. Victor, bring it right in here. Look - look at that. That is amazing.

PRICE: That's the 27th one the Yankees have given out to players.

KEENE: I've got my Mickey Mantle belt buckle on, but -

PRICE: There you go. Now we're talking.

KEENE: - I'm not going to show it right here. A Mickey Mantle belt buckle, I saw him steal second base once at Fenway Park. That was great.

We've got to go. Michael Price, thank you so much.

12:18

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF MFP INVESTORS LLC, TALKS ABOUT INVESTMENT AND M&A ON BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

DECEMBER 2, 2010

SPEAKERS: MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

12:01

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE: Michael Price joining us now of MFP Investors. Is legendary too much of a -

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC: Yes.

KEENE: - should I not say legendary?

PRICE: So are you.

KEENE: Good to see you.

PRICE: Good to see you.

KEENE: Let's just start with the state of value investing. When you wake up in the morning, is there a lot of value out there or was that so 2009?

PRICE: There are pockets. There are pockets. Yesterday we had a big day, so, you know, it closed that gap. But, yes, we are finding some things to do. When you see mergers announced at 40 percent premiums to where stocks are trading like Del Monte, Baldor Electric, right?

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: It tells you there is still value out there.

KEENE: And the mergers it just seems to pick up. In talking to Jonathan Keehner on our M&A team, they are enthused about having fun in 2011. Does it just keep rolling here with an economic recovery?

PRICE: It keeps rolling until some investment bank puts up a bridge loan and they cannot place it. Then all of a sudden it grinds to a halt. It starts rolling until there is a problem in -

KEENE: Okay. Let's -

PRICE: So some of these are being announced with bridge loans.

KEENE: Yes, let's look at the "dreaded first chart" here. Michael Price with us here. This is Jason Trennert's chart from Strategas. I'll steal from anyone, Michael. This is a Jason chart. This is the Nasdaq 100 to the S&P 500, growth back in vogue. Do you find value in what you and I perceive is value? Or do you find value in growth?

PRICE: Both. You know, we are long some growthy kind of stocks.

KEENE: Give me some examples.

PRICE: We're long some e-Bay. And if you back out the cash, you back out their value in Skype, and you look at the two parts of e-Bay, I mean you can make an argument that it is pretty cheap and that is a growthy stock.

KEENE: Casey, make up an e-Bay chart going back at least 15 years, 20 years, whatever. Just see what you can do with that.

Look at this chart. This is great. Emily, thanks for bringing this up.

PRICE: 3PAR, 3PAR up.

KEENE: Were you an owner?

PRICE: No, hold on. We own a comparable -

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: - that is actually privately owned ConneXium. 3PAR is in the storage business, and Compellent, Epsilon, and 3PAR were taken over at huge numbers - Compellent not yet, but it probably will be - at seven times, ten times revenues.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: Fifty, 60 times earnings. Crazy numbers. By guys like EMC, Joe Tucci, and others who really don't care. Another billion here or there doesn't really matter to them.

KEENE: Yes, that's the way I am.

PRICE: But, you know, the valuations are crazy.

KEENE: And you look at 3PAR, and the reason I put this up, look at this chart. I had to get my bow tie straight.

PRICE: Well, we're very well aware of it.

KEENE: I wore this red - this is a Red Sox bow tie.

PRICE: I wore my Yankee -

KEENE: You wore your Yankee - that's good. You wore - did you see that? I have the dumb red bow tie. You've got - put that ring up again, let's look at that. Get in here for a close up. I'm proud that you're wearing that ring.

PRICE: (Inaudible) it's about to sign (inaudible).

KEENE: What's Jeter doing?

PRICE: Derek Jeter.

KEENE: What's he going to do?

PRICE: Well, I understand that he has got a very fair offer on the table.

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: So it should be taken. But we'll see -

KEENE: Well, let's - back to 3PAR. Back to investment. Over on the right side of this chart is the game theory here involved, where two players, three players get involved. When you are a value owner, that is your dream.

PRICE: That's the dream. You have a bid for a company. If someone else came into Del Monte because of the pet food business, which is the key, you know, off to the races. If someone comes in - Boone Pickens as a part Exco with a group -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - if someone else shows up, it is off to the races.

KEENE: And what you do, you are known for careful analysis, not just going in quickly, careful analysis.

PRICE: We do a little work.

KEENE: Do you look at the strategic -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - selections down the road, the companies that would come in?

PRICE: Absolutely. Strategic is better than financial, right? You want a strategic buyer. The ABB bid for Baldor, which owns Reliance Electric, is strategic. They market together. They will promote together. They manufacture together. That is strategic. That is a better buyer than a KKR.

KEENE: Let's look at a disaster - M&A sale Alcatel-Lucent. This has been a train wreck since time began. I'm going -

PRICE: It still is.

KEENE: - to be polite and not ask if you own this dog up there.

PRICE: No, we were never involved.

KEENE: But how does this happen?

PRICE: I cannot help you there. We were not involved.

KEENE: You were not involved, but when you look at dinosaurs mating as some would say, but in my language a lot of people have written about this.

PRICE: Yes, but out of Alcatel-Lucent, we will get involved when they spin something off that is going to be too cheap. So these companies reinvent themselves numerous ways, and Wall Street stands in there to make markets and new securities.

You know, we have spin offs every day. We had an IPO today of something called FXCM that came out of the Refco bankruptcy. I mean that was an interesting situation, a currency trading firm.

KEENE: Which sector is the most attractive right now? Everybody is telling me technology, technology, technology. Where are you?

PRICE: Well, tech is interesting. We are not big tech players. I think natural gas is pretty interesting. Between the shale plays and regular gas producers, gas has lagged oil quite a bit.

KEENE: Where will the market in general go next year?

PRICE: Stocks? I have no idea.

KEENE: You don't really care, do you?

PRICE: I don't like the bond market.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And gold is a bubble, and I don't like the ten year. But stocks in general are reasonable here. I think there are a few pockets of cheapness, but here and there they are where they should be.

KEENE: Michael Price with us, folks. We're going to come back and continue our discussion with Mr. Price about M&A into next year.

12:06

(BREAK)

12:10

KEENE: Michael Price with me. He has been bragging about his New York Yankees World Series Championship, King of the World ring. Thank you for bringing that in.

Wheat - here's an exogenous event. Wheat surges on drought. Do you just stay focused on 20 or 40 or 50 stocks, or do you care about the stuff I babble about all day?

PRICE: No, we don't do the macro, but we look at hundreds of stocks. A lot more than 20 or 40.

KEENE: Global macro seems to be the vogue now -

PRICE: Yes, but that's not what we do.

KEENE: - with hedge fund resisting.

PRICE: That's not what we do.

KEENE: Is it global macro is right, and then they get it wrong and everybody goes back to playing (inaudible), classic long/short.

PRICE: Yes, I'm excited in that they are global. They are going away from the U.S. market. Let them go into Brazil. That gives me more things to do here, less competition I think. Let them get distracted.

KEENE: Talk about the American malaise, the idea that America is not doing that well and that you see this wall of worry, recovery in equities.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: And, you know -

PRICE: It is last spring and summer. I mean it was everybody was so skeptical and yet you have this fantastic economy that is slowly churning ahead. The car loadings at Berkshire Hathaway, Burlington Northern reported were very impressive.

KEENE: Phenomenal, yes.

PRICE: The truck tons that they report are very impressive. The economy is churning around.

KEENE: Emily, go the Goldman Sachs note, please, if you would. This is the "note of the day." And we're going to go to the note of the day here, folks, we rip up the script. We do that all the time. Drives them nuts in the control room. Goldman Sachs global research, this is Jim O'Neill's former desk, room to grow. We expect the most significant shift to take place in the U.S. Four percent 2012.

PRICE: But it is the valuations. You know, here you can buy at low teens multiples terrific U.S. worldwide and U.S. companies participate in it with better regulation I think here than around the world. So I think it is not only better, but cheaper here.

KEENE: Let's keep Goldman Sachs up here just because we brought up the note. Here is the stock. Is big Wall Street going to lead the way? Or do you -

PRICE: I think it is so interesting.

KEENE: - believe the boutiques are going to do it?

PRICE: I am going to tell you I think some boutiques are set up very well. The Greenhills of the world are terrific. They are focused.

Other boutiques have conflicts. You know, Cowen runs something called Ramius. Cowen is trying to get investment banking business at the same time Ramius is doing hostile 13Ds against some of the companies. It doesn't make sense.

Goldman should split up into three parts. They should have money management, trading, and investment banking. Investment banking requires little or no equity. Money management little or no equity. They plow some equity into the trading business -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - and spin off the big dividend.

KEENE: Okay, this is very explicit right here. This is important. We're going to stay on this. Forget about the rest of the stuff. Goldman Sachs, let's start again.

PRICE: We own the stock.

KEENE: Should they be - you own the stock.

PRICE: We own the stock. The stock -

KEENE: There's the chart up here, folks.

PRICE: The stock is reasonably priced. It is a terrific business, okay? And I remember watching Fidelity, the big mutual fund company, back when everything went well for them in the eighties and nineties, got too big. And I said to them why don't you split up into three, four parts. A bond fund, equity, this and that.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: They never did and they kind of languished in the last ten years.

KEENE: Did you go long the day of the testimony?

PRICE: We traded in the stock, yes.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: When you look at Goldman Sachs, the first step is should they stay a bank or do they go - do they leave the banking number all over government.

PRICE: I think they should become three entities which requires one being a bank. You know, the trading - they have a trading business. They have a banking business and a money management business. They do not have to be together. They can free up capital. They can get higher valuations. I think the stock would be $250 if they did that.

KEENE: Let's go back to the little banks. You mentioned Greenhill before. I think of Evercore, what Altman is doing there.

PRICE: Another one.

KEENE: There is an independence there. Are they getting the smartest people?

PRICE: Some of them are getting very good people, sure. Cowen has been hiring good people. And buried inside of the biggest bank - Bank of America - is Merrill. When they start hitting on all cylinders, getting past the mortgage put back mess, Bank of America is a powerful franchise.

KEENE: Is Morgan -

PRICE: And people forget that they own Merrill -

KEENE: Is Morgan Stanley strapped because of all these broker deal mortgages?

PRICE: Yes, Morgan Stanley has got other issues, sure they do.

KEENE: They've got other issues.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: Let's go back here. Could you bring up e-Bay, Emily? I know we are throwing it around here with Michael Price, but let's bring up e-Bay. I am surprised you mentioned this name. They're working on it back in the control room. They've got to get the gerbil going to bring it up.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: There it is. They fed the gerbil, good.

Okay, e-Bay back a decade, I'm going to be blunt. IPO up it goes.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: Stupid price, and it has gone nowhere. Is that a safe summary?

PRICE: Well, it has gone from $12 to $29.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And at $12 bucks where we kind of got involved - $12 and $15 I think it was, I mean we were paying under ten times earnings for their basic business, getting other stuff for free. They did not go sell a slug of the Skype.

And their Paypal business is going to be probably one of the most valuable businesses going forward. Everybody wants to get into electronic trunk funds transfer -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - secure electronic funds transfer.

KEENE: Well -

PRICE: VeriFone is doing it. VeriFone stock has been a rocket this year. It will continue to go. e-Bay I think is really interesting.

KEENE: Sheila Dharmarajan was out here the other night - yesterday, rather, talking up NetFlix. When you see the silliness of NetFlix, can you distill that down? Is it a profit model you can stay with?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: You have not looked at it?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: When you looked at e-Bay I thought maybe you'd look at -

PRICE: That was -

KEENE: Give me another name. What else are you looking at besides e- Bay?

PRICE: Well, we own some big industrials. You know, we still own our Ingersoll Rand, which I like a lot.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: We do some other parts today. It is getting pretty full, but if you have some growth going forward, it is a cheap stock. The balance sheet has gotten much better as they have paid down debt.

KEENE: I see Emerson Electric with 57 percent global. It is amazing these industrials how they have gone global.

PRICE: And you can get a big currency benefit, too.

KEENE: Let's look at Colgate Palmolive here. I want to talk to Michael Price about investing 101 here. We're going to bring up Colgate, which is has just done great for ten and 12 years.

Not your kind of stock, but this goes back to the people that aren't Michael Price. How do you know when to sell? Or do you just go with buy and hold if you not as sophisticated?

PRICE: Selling is much tougher. You know, I think you buy things when things are 30 or 40 percent below what you think the asset value is. Selling it is very hard to tell. So we tend to dribble them out slowly as they move up.

KEENE: As they move up -

PRICE: I don't know the valuation of Colgate so I cannot help you there.

KEENE: No, I understand the valuation of Colgate. I just brought it up with this, you know, buy and hold strategy. We are seeing so many individual investors really looking at dividend reinvestment as an important way to go.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: I mean you don't care about that. It is much more strategic.

PRICE: There are some large cap - Microsoft is one, IBM is one, Johnson & Johnson - where good investors have made the arguments that these are very cheap, 12, 13 times earnings, with a dividend yield of three or four percent. And they are right. They are basically right. These stocks are pretty cheap looking over a decade.

KEENE: When you look at this, what is your single message for 2011?

PRICE: I think you have to be constructive. I think you have to look at - you know, that this economy is going to do better even in spite of somewhat higher interest rates.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: You are going to churn ahead and I think you will find opportunities, so you have got to pay attention.

KEENE: I want to talk another sector. You mentioned the U.S. field, you are not looking abroad.

PRICE: No.

KEENE: You are using the U.S. component -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - placed abroad. When you look at the dollar filtering in there, that has got to benefit some people here almost either way. I mean the U.S. is doing better than Europe, aren't they?

PRICE: Yes, the U.S. is going to do better. I think the problems in Europe are the PIIGS and they may be spreading a little bit. You know, we have that further out, so I think the focus will be on them first hurting the euro. And then unfortunately helping the dollar, which won't be that good in the short term.

KEENE: Humility is a big part of this. What is the biggest mistake you have made? I don't mean like the specific story, but philosophically in investment what is the thing that got you into the most hot water?

PRICE: Oh, probably getting into large positions where you really cannot exit. You know -

KEENE: Too big a position.

PRICE: - you are the lead guy and, yes, I mean -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - Sunbeam Oster comes to mind from way back.

KEENE: Show me that ring again. We've got to get one more look at this, Victor. Get in. Move the coffee cup. Victor, bring it right in here. Look - look at that. That is amazing.

PRICE: That's the 27th one the Yankees have given out to players.

KEENE: I've got my Mickey Mantle belt buckle on, but -

PRICE: There you go. Now we're talking.

KEENE: - I'm not going to show it right here. A Mickey Mantle belt buckle, I saw him steal second base once at Fenway Park. That was great.

We've got to go. Michael Price, thank you so much.

12:18

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF MFP INVESTORS LLC

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC

TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG MIDDAY SURVEILLANCE: Michael Price joining us now of MFP Investors. Is legendary too much of a -

MICHAEL PRICE, MANAGING DIRECTOR, MFP INVESTORS LLC: Yes.

KEENE: - should I not say legendary?

PRICE: So are you.

KEENE: Good to see you.

PRICE: Good to see you.

KEENE: Let's just start with the state of value investing. When you wake up in the morning, is there a lot of value out there or was that so 2009?

PRICE: There are pockets. There are pockets. Yesterday we had a big day, so, you know, it closed that gap. But, yes, we are finding some things to do. When you see mergers announced at 40 percent premiums to where stocks are trading like Del Monte, Baldor Electric, right?

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: It tells you there is still value out there.

KEENE: And the mergers it just seems to pick up. In talking to Jonathan Keehner on our M&A team, they are enthused about having fun in 2011. Does it just keep rolling here with an economic recovery?

PRICE: It keeps rolling until some investment bank puts up a bridge loan and they cannot place it. Then all of a sudden it grinds to a halt. It starts rolling until there is a problem in -

KEENE: Okay. Let's -

PRICE: So some of these are being announced with bridge loans.

KEENE: Yes, let's look at the "dreaded first chart" here. Michael Price with us here. This is Jason Trennert's chart from Strategas. I'll steal from anyone, Michael. This is a Jason chart. This is the Nasdaq 100 to the S&P 500, growth back in vogue. Do you find value in what you and I perceive is value? Or do you find value in growth?

PRICE: Both. You know, we are long some growthy kind of stocks.

KEENE: Give me some examples.

PRICE: We're long some e-Bay. And if you back out the cash, you back out their value in Skype, and you look at the two parts of e-Bay, I mean you can make an argument that it is pretty cheap and that is a growthy stock.

KEENE: Casey, make up an e-Bay chart going back at least 15 years, 20 years, whatever. Just see what you can do with that.

Look at this chart. This is great. Emily, thanks for bringing this up.

PRICE: 3PAR, 3PAR up.

KEENE: Were you an owner?

PRICE: No, hold on. We own a comparable -

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: - that is actually privately owned ConneXium. 3PAR is in the storage business, and Compellent, Epsilon, and 3PAR were taken over at huge numbers - Compellent not yet, but it probably will be - at seven times, ten times revenues.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: Fifty, 60 times earnings. Crazy numbers. By guys like EMC, Joe Tucci, and others who really don't care. Another billion here or there doesn't really matter to them.

KEENE: Yes, that's the way I am.

PRICE: But, you know, the valuations are crazy.

KEENE: And you look at 3PAR, and the reason I put this up, look at this chart. I had to get my bow tie straight.

PRICE: Well, we're very well aware of it.

KEENE: I wore this red - this is a Red Sox bow tie.

PRICE: I wore my Yankee -

KEENE: You wore your Yankee - that's good. You wore - did you see that? I have the dumb red bow tie. You've got - put that ring up again, let's look at that. Get in here for a close up. I'm proud that you're wearing that ring.

PRICE: (Inaudible) it's about to sign (inaudible).

KEENE: What's Jeter doing?

PRICE: Derek Jeter.

KEENE: What's he going to do?

PRICE: Well, I understand that he has got a very fair offer on the table.

KEENE: Okay.

PRICE: So it should be taken. But we'll see -

KEENE: Well, let's - back to 3PAR. Back to investment. Over on the right side of this chart is the game theory here involved, where two players, three players get involved. When you are a value owner, that is your dream.

PRICE: That's the dream. You have a bid for a company. If someone else came into Del Monte because of the pet food business, which is the key, you know, off to the races. If someone comes in - Boone Pickens as a part Exco with a group -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - if someone else shows up, it is off to the races.

KEENE: And what you do, you are known for careful analysis, not just going in quickly, careful analysis.

PRICE: We do a little work.

KEENE: Do you look at the strategic -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - selections down the road, the companies that would come in?

PRICE: Absolutely. Strategic is better than financial, right? You want a strategic buyer. The ABB bid for Baldor, which owns Reliance Electric, is strategic. They market together. They will promote together. They manufacture together. That is strategic. That is a better buyer than a KKR.

KEENE: Let's look at a disaster - M&A sale Alcatel-Lucent. This has been a train wreck since time began. I'm going -

PRICE: It still is.

KEENE: - to be polite and not ask if you own this dog up there.

PRICE: No, we were never involved.

KEENE: But how does this happen?

PRICE: I cannot help you there. We were not involved.

KEENE: You were not involved, but when you look at dinosaurs mating as some would say, but in my language a lot of people have written about this.

PRICE: Yes, but out of Alcatel-Lucent, we will get involved when they spin something off that is going to be too cheap. So these companies reinvent themselves numerous ways, and Wall Street stands in there to make markets and new securities.

You know, we have spin offs every day. We had an IPO today of something called FXCM that came out of the Refco bankruptcy. I mean that was an interesting situation, a currency trading firm.

KEENE: Which sector is the most attractive right now? Everybody is telling me technology, technology, technology. Where are you?

PRICE: Well, tech is interesting. We are not big tech players. I think natural gas is pretty interesting. Between the shale plays and regular gas producers, gas has lagged oil quite a bit.

KEENE: Where will the market in general go next year?

PRICE: Stocks? I have no idea.

KEENE: You don't really care, do you?

PRICE: I don't like the bond market.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And gold is a bubble, and I don't like the ten year. But stocks in general are reasonable here. I think there are a few pockets of cheapness, but here and there they are where they should be.

KEENE: Michael Price with us, folks. We're going to come back and continue our discussion with Mr. Price about M&A into next year.

12:06

(BREAK)

12:10

KEENE: Michael Price with me. He has been bragging about his New York Yankees World Series Championship, King of the World ring. Thank you for bringing that in.

Wheat - here's an exogenous event. Wheat surges on drought. Do you just stay focused on 20 or 40 or 50 stocks, or do you care about the stuff I babble about all day?

PRICE: No, we don't do the macro, but we look at hundreds of stocks. A lot more than 20 or 40.

KEENE: Global macro seems to be the vogue now -

PRICE: Yes, but that's not what we do.

KEENE: - with hedge fund resisting.

PRICE: That's not what we do.

KEENE: Is it global macro is right, and then they get it wrong and everybody goes back to playing (inaudible), classic long/short.

PRICE: Yes, I'm excited in that they are global. They are going away from the U.S. market. Let them go into Brazil. That gives me more things to do here, less competition I think. Let them get distracted.

KEENE: Talk about the American malaise, the idea that America is not doing that well and that you see this wall of worry, recovery in equities.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: And, you know -

PRICE: It is last spring and summer. I mean it was everybody was so skeptical and yet you have this fantastic economy that is slowly churning ahead. The car loadings at Berkshire Hathaway, Burlington Northern reported were very impressive.

KEENE: Phenomenal, yes.

PRICE: The truck tons that they report are very impressive. The economy is churning around.

KEENE: Emily, go the Goldman Sachs note, please, if you would. This is the "note of the day." And we're going to go to the note of the day here, folks, we rip up the script. We do that all the time. Drives them nuts in the control room. Goldman Sachs global research, this is Jim O'Neill's former desk, room to grow. We expect the most significant shift to take place in the U.S. Four percent 2012.

PRICE: But it is the valuations. You know, here you can buy at low teens multiples terrific U.S. worldwide and U.S. companies participate in it with better regulation I think here than around the world. So I think it is not only better, but cheaper here.

KEENE: Let's keep Goldman Sachs up here just because we brought up the note. Here is the stock. Is big Wall Street going to lead the way? Or do you -

PRICE: I think it is so interesting.

KEENE: - believe the boutiques are going to do it?

PRICE: I am going to tell you I think some boutiques are set up very well. The Greenhills of the world are terrific. They are focused.

Other boutiques have conflicts. You know, Cowen runs something called Ramius. Cowen is trying to get investment banking business at the same time Ramius is doing hostile 13Ds against some of the companies. It doesn't make sense.

Goldman should split up into three parts. They should have money management, trading, and investment banking. Investment banking requires little or no equity. Money management little or no equity. They plow some equity into the trading business -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - and spin off the big dividend.

KEENE: Okay, this is very explicit right here. This is important. We're going to stay on this. Forget about the rest of the stuff. Goldman Sachs, let's start again.

PRICE: We own the stock.

KEENE: Should they be - you own the stock.

PRICE: We own the stock. The stock -

KEENE: There's the chart up here, folks.

PRICE: The stock is reasonably priced. It is a terrific business, okay? And I remember watching Fidelity, the big mutual fund company, back when everything went well for them in the eighties and nineties, got too big. And I said to them why don't you split up into three, four parts. A bond fund, equity, this and that.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: They never did and they kind of languished in the last ten years.

KEENE: Did you go long the day of the testimony?

PRICE: We traded in the stock, yes.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: When you look at Goldman Sachs, the first step is should they stay a bank or do they go - do they leave the banking number all over government.

PRICE: I think they should become three entities which requires one being a bank. You know, the trading - they have a trading business. They have a banking business and a money management business. They do not have to be together. They can free up capital. They can get higher valuations. I think the stock would be $250 if they did that.

KEENE: Let's go back to the little banks. You mentioned Greenhill before. I think of Evercore, what Altman is doing there.

PRICE: Another one.

KEENE: There is an independence there. Are they getting the smartest people?

PRICE: Some of them are getting very good people, sure. Cowen has been hiring good people. And buried inside of the biggest bank - Bank of America - is Merrill. When they start hitting on all cylinders, getting past the mortgage put back mess, Bank of America is a powerful franchise.

KEENE: Is Morgan -

PRICE: And people forget that they own Merrill -

KEENE: Is Morgan Stanley strapped because of all these broker deal mortgages?

PRICE: Yes, Morgan Stanley has got other issues, sure they do.

KEENE: They've got other issues.

PRICE: Yes.

KEENE: Let's go back here. Could you bring up e-Bay, Emily? I know we are throwing it around here with Michael Price, but let's bring up e-Bay. I am surprised you mentioned this name. They're working on it back in the control room. They've got to get the gerbil going to bring it up.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: There it is. They fed the gerbil, good.

Okay, e-Bay back a decade, I'm going to be blunt. IPO up it goes.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: Stupid price, and it has gone nowhere. Is that a safe summary?

PRICE: Well, it has gone from $12 to $29.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: And at $12 bucks where we kind of got involved - $12 and $15 I think it was, I mean we were paying under ten times earnings for their basic business, getting other stuff for free. They did not go sell a slug of the Skype.

And their Paypal business is going to be probably one of the most valuable businesses going forward. Everybody wants to get into electronic trunk funds transfer -

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: - secure electronic funds transfer.

KEENE: Well -

PRICE: VeriFone is doing it. VeriFone stock has been a rocket this year. It will continue to go. e-Bay I think is really interesting.

KEENE: Sheila Dharmarajan was out here the other night - yesterday, rather, talking up NetFlix. When you see the silliness of NetFlix, can you distill that down? Is it a profit model you can stay with?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: You have not looked at it?

PRICE: I don't know.

KEENE: When you looked at e-Bay I thought maybe you'd look at -

PRICE: That was -

KEENE: Give me another name. What else are you looking at besides e-Bay?

PRICE: Well, we own some big industrials. You know, we still own our Ingersoll Rand, which I like a lot.

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: We do some other parts today. It is getting pretty full, but if you have some growth going forward, it is a cheap stock. The balance sheet has gotten much better as they have paid down debt.

KEENE: I see Emerson Electric with 57 percent global. It is amazing these industrials how they have gone global.

PRICE: And you can get a big currency benefit, too.

KEENE: Let's look at Colgate Palmolive here. I want to talk to Michael Price about investing 101 here. We're going to bring up Colgate, which is has just done great for ten and 12 years.

Not your kind of stock, but this goes back to the people that aren't Michael Price. How do you know when to sell? Or do you just go with buy and hold if you not as sophisticated?

PRICE: Selling is much tougher. You know, I think you buy things when things are 30 or 40 percent below what you think the asset value is. Selling it is very hard to tell. So we tend to dribble them out slowly as they move up.

KEENE: As they move up -

PRICE: I don't know the valuation of Colgate so I cannot help you there.

KEENE: No, I understand the valuation of Colgate. I just brought it up with this, you know, buy and hold strategy. We are seeing so many individual investors really looking at dividend reinvestment as an important way to go.

PRICE: Right.

KEENE: I mean you don't care about that. It is much more strategic.

PRICE: There are some large cap - Microsoft is one, IBM is one, Johnson & Johnson - where good investors have made the arguments that these are very cheap, 12, 13 times earnings, with a dividend yield of three or four percent. And they are right. They are basically right. These stocks are pretty cheap looking over a decade.

KEENE: When you look at this, what is your single message for 2011?

PRICE: I think you have to be constructive. I think you have to look at - you know, that this economy is going to do better even in spite of somewhat higher interest rates.

KEENE: Right.

PRICE: You are going to churn ahead and I think you will find opportunities, so you have got to pay attention.

KEENE: I want to talk another sector. You mentioned the U.S. field, you are not looking abroad.

PRICE: No.

KEENE: You are using the U.S. component -

PRICE: Sure.

KEENE: - placed abroad. When you look at the dollar filtering in there, that has got to benefit some people here almost either way. I mean the U.S. is doing better than Europe, aren't they?

PRICE: Yes, the U.S. is going to do better. I think the problems in Europe are the PIIGS and they may be spreading a little bit. You know, we have that further out, so I think the focus will be on them first hurting the euro. And then unfortunately helping the dollar, which won't be that good in the short term.

KEENE: Humility is a big part of this. What is the biggest mistake you have made? I don't mean like the specific story, but philosophically in investment what is the thing that got you into the most hot water?

PRICE: Oh, probably getting into large positions where you really cannot exit. You know -

KEENE: Too big a position.

PRICE: - you are the lead guy and, yes, I mean -

KEENE: Yes.

PRICE: - Sunbeam Oster comes to mind from way back.

KEENE: Show me that ring again. We've got to get one more look at this, Victor. Get in. Move the coffee cup. Victor, bring it right in here. Look - look at that. That is amazing.

PRICE: That's the 27th one the Yankees have given out to players.

KEENE: I've got my Mickey Mantle belt buckle on, but -

PRICE: There you go. Now we're talking.

KEENE: - I'm not going to show it right here. A Mickey Mantle belt buckle, I saw him steal second base once at Fenway Park. That was great.

We've got to go. Michael Price, thank you so much.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
